text.quote: Large, enduring market with stalls selling local foods & souvenirs, plus clothing & household items.
trip: This is a very large market with open air stalls, and some in closed areas, with everything from shoes to children's items to food to everything in between. I went with an item in mind and found it - although it took about 15 minutes of looking. Don't buy at the first stalls at
Unfortunately, the place was more than dirty. It was stinky actually!!! Meat was thown everywhere around and the smell was awfull!!! I was so disapointed when visited this place.
Too large to see everything...! As I came in December, I could see unusual marchandise: someone sell potatoes on truck. If you go there, recommend to have a brief plan :)

Chorsu is the central market of Tashkent. The locals do their shopping here but the place can be interesting for someone visiting the city. The interior section is majestically big and there are a few nice shops for handicrafts. The prices are lower than the ordinary tourist
Local market mostly crowded with locals. Of you do not have dry fruit shopping, can be avoided......
Had heard so much about this place that we were rather disappointed. The stores were mediocre and the goods of a very average quality.
The chorsu is the biggest market area I have ever seen. You can find everything in this bazaar but it is really chaotic place.

Chorsu Bazaar feels incredibly authentic, and is like nothing you’ll see in the West. Truthfully, I didn’t find any of the things on offer particularly appealing (and the stuff on sale for tourists isn’t particularly exciting), but the whole draw of Chorsu Bazaar for me are the
This covered bazaar is wonderful to stroll through, especially the nut, fruit and vegetable sections where the produce looks fabulous. We did not find the clothing and souvenir stalls enticing.
Nice traditional bazaar with all the hustle and bustle of a bazaar. A variety of food and other items available
A must if you want to see a glimpse of everyday life. Good place to get cheap items (snacks and trinkets). Make sure to get a meal at the row of open air restaurants - really good stuff there.

Classic veg/meat/fruits/spices/ all kinds of household stuff market for locals. Tourists get charged at least 10times the price the locals get, no matter how you bargain, they rather won't sell than give you a reasonable price. Not worth the journey from the other side of the

I visited the market twice, once for looking and the other to buy a bag to take back Uzbek crafts. The market is a site to see and fun, especially in the food sections (for foodies like me). My bag ended up being barely strong enough to carry my stuff back to Canada so be

Worth a visit . I can’t say more . Prices vary if you can bargain your good . The place is good for understanding how much meat and cheese Uzbek people eat. One of the biggest meat and cheese markets Ive seen in my life . Outside the market its very big and you can find

We came to Chorsu Bazaar on a Sunday around noon. The Chorsu metro can also get you here. The market is large. There are sections for meats, fruits and vegetables. If you go to the 2nd floor, you can get an overview of the entire area. If you exit the round dome building,

A very large, confusing area with hundreds (thousands?) of vendors selling a huge variety of things. At its centre is a domed indoor market selling meat, cheese and (upstairs) a vast array of nuts and dried fruits. Perfect for your last day in Tashkent when you're hoping to buy

One of the few 'Must sees' in Tashkent and it is worth it. It is very much a working market and thankfully not touristifyed. You need small denomination of som just in case! Great variety of produce, no hassle. Great to see bread being made -every tourist must be brought to see

We went on Sunday - a bad day to visit, lots and lots of people! There is so much stuff there, for everyone’s taste. My absolute favorite were nuts - I love nuts, and there are so many to choose from! I also enjoyed the spices, vegetables, and various salads. And, of course,

No visit to Tashkent can be complete without spending a few hours in Chorsu. Its scale and spread are mind-blowing! Flowers, fruits, meats, dry fruits, bread, clothes, bags, souvenirs, bakery, local food, salads, whatever you can imagine is available. The most remarkable

Chorus Bazaar is a sprawling indoor and outdoor market which seems like Central Asia's answer to Bangkok's Chatachak Market. For dedicated market enthusiasts, this one will deliver, as it offers everything from gold to terracotta and cashews to silk. We are not keen shoppers,
Visited twice the bazar . I did most of my shopping from Chorsu Bazar. Best place to buy dry fruits , fresh Uzbek Bread . Tasty local food .

Chorsu bazaar is the biggest market place of Tashkent. You will get everything here right from souvenirs, handicrafts, crockeries, fruits, vegetables, nuts, dryfruits, milk products, local cuisines, restaurants, money exchange and a metro station too which opens right in the

My can driver was butt and dropped me off a block away across the street but friendly locals got me to the right place. The place is huge. People are hustling and selling and negotiating all over the place. Do not ever pay full price. Cut in half and negotiate. Here is English

Charsu is a huge bazaar that sells everything from exotic meats and fruits to handy crafts and many will enjoy a treasure hunt in it's vast streets and enclaves. It was not my cup of tea as I could not stand the smell of meat, or the chaos that surrounds it. But I probably paid

The Chorsu Bazaar provided a look at how the local people in Tashkent live. Access is via the Metro and ext at Chorsu Station.The market was full of people and had atmosphere and was clean and neat and well organized.You will find everything you need here and some things you do

chorrsu bazar in tashkent is a small world in itself here you will find local people and tourists purchasing dryfruits vegetalbles and gifts and stationery items THE bazar gives you a feeling of the old world charm with a lot of bargaining to purchase your required items
The smells, the food, the people, just the whole place in general is fantastic! There are so many different vendors showcasing their local goods. An absolute must do while in Tashkent!
The bazar was a centre of old Tashkent and as the name suggests it is circular complex with entry from all four sides. Go shopping for local dry fruits and fresh fruits

Recommended for all travelers who would like to obtain souvenirs, National jewelry, carpets , clothes and many other things. Inexpensive bazaar! Kindly recommend for travelers to go there with the local friends in order to avoid highly offered prices by shopkeepers:)) anyways,

This is a must see in Tashkent. Could be seen multiple times because the make up of the vendor's stalls and the expressions on the people's faces changes often. Be prepared for a sensory overload and remember the entrance so you can find your way back out because there is

A nice place to visit since it provides safe, enjoyable and economic tourism. Hotels, food and transport are cheap. History and monuments are impressive. People are excellent and hospitable. Dry fruits are must purchase. The value for money spent is high.
Great place to bargain for dry fruits and to roam around to get a feel of the bazaar style haggling of times gone by.

The Chorsu Bazaar in Tashkent is an interesting market for all sorts of products ranging from vegetables, soveniors, food and various other items. One section that was particularly interesting was the bread section where bakers bake bread in huge clay ovens and one can buy them
For someone on a business trip for Licorice we very disappointed by the amount or weak availability. A lot of spices Vendors are nice.

VERY large bazzar (we traveled for half a day and still haven't seen half of it). I thought the market was just the dome in the middle, but it's just a tiny fraction of the market. Lots of street food , fruits, vegetables, souviners, spices, knives.. you name it. Pretty much

At first Chorsu Bazaar looked exciting but as I looked closely I realized all the merchants sell nearly the same things. There's very little variety and it gets boring quite quickly. If you don't like crowded, hot places then this is not the right place for you. You won't get

It’s a Nazarene - hot busy and noisy and huge We arrived at 0700 as the stalls were being set up - amazing experience - left at twelve as the days heat started Bought alsorts and spent very little Yes the meat room smells - we just avoided it Great experience - noise -
Spent a few hours here walking around. It is a very local market. The best part was watching the Non bread being made and cooked. Then buying a fresh loaf for 1500 som and eating it hot.
Loads of market stalls, with many kids hassling you to buy from them. A rather off putting smell of raw meat on the lower floor.

Chorsu has variety but if you are a connoisseur, don't expect great quality. Value for money, Yes. Good variety of dry fruits. It's ironic and paradoxical, the place of origin never provides great quality in local markets, perhaps because export fetches the green bucks. Friendly
Chorus is an must experience! Market us where you get to see the kind and welcoming culture of Uzbekistan.
Nice place to see the bazaar and buy nuts and other food items back for your Friends and family back home.

The Bazaar is a central dome shaped structure surrounded by a huge array of stalks outside. My favourite was the bread bazaar with wonderful smells, if you like butchered meat smells the main dime is the place for you. Lots of animal carcasses hanging and kits of huge trays of

Very busy and lots to see! The meat section was fascinating and the fresh fruit and vegetables were cheap and good. The bakery section was great especially eating a piece of bread straight out of the oven!
We got a good products with convenient fairs , lot of different souvenirs and even gifts from owners , clean area. Complements

You must visit this bazaar if you visit Tashkent: so vast and so well organised - a joy to wander around even if you're not planning to buy anything. The displays are fabulous and you will end up buying some fruit, spices or nuts - they just look so good and the prices are

Probably one of the largest Bazaar I have seen. This market is huge and sells everything, you can spend hours wandering around, Do not miss the huge Dome in the middle where the meat sellers are, it is quite a site ! People are very friendly and will often give you some of
I loved visiting this market were you will interact with local that are extremely welcoming. The fresh bread is a must try.

It was raining and quite cold when we visited Chorsu Bazaar in Tashkent. So much to see and so much to buy. Great place to buy dry fruits and the variety is just endless. Some amount of bargaining is required and the shopkeepers are friendly and eager to please. They allow you

I really wish I didn't waste my time. So many stalls selling junk and animals in disgusting conditions. Also a variety of roosters which have obviously been used for fighting. There is a great range of fruit, vegetables and spices which I enjoyed. Everything else was

It’s nothing special selling yet special experience. From farm fresh vegetables to 22 carat gold jewellery to horse meat to Adrus. You can come out without impulse buying. You can’t call your Tashkent trip complete without visiting it. Souvenirs are cheaper then market and more

This enormous covered market is amazing. It is on 2 levels. We were fortunate to be here in Ramadan when many of the stall are closed and many people do not come. At least we could walk around and see things - usually it is so crowded that getting around is tricky let alone
worth visiting. The place where east meets west.There you can find everything, from food to clothing.It is so colorfull .
One of the must sees while visiting Tashkent! So much to see and even to buy and try! Oh my god the bread is amazing!
Nice to walk around - well ordered - clean After you finish go to the back - down the steps and then have a simple adhoc lunch with the locals
Chorsu Bazaar is the best place in Tashkent where you can feel real Uzbekistan. Local food and very nice and friendly people.

Chorsu Bazaar is touted as a must see in Tashkent but it was basically a huge big mess of a market place. As a tourist, there is a small section that sold crafts that would be interesting but most of the place was produce, dried good, and meat that wouldn’t interest the visitor

This must be one of the largest bazaars I've been to - and the variety was staggering - sections specialising from meat to vegetables to bread, sweets and dried fruits. Not to forget the usual market fare of clothing Very easy to get to as it's by the Chorsu metro

Chorsu Bazaar is a huge market in Tashkent. You can buy just about anything in its many halls and rooms. The giant dome is very impressive. The bread making area is particularly interesting. A must for market lovers.

Always like to visit there during my visit to tashkent. Wide variety of fruits vegetables and dry fruits which attracts. Neat and clean area with good hospitable people. Beware there is heavy bargaining and careful while buying things , ask them for best option and quality
Good market for dry fruits you will get dry fruits for unbelievable price and very wide range but you have to bargain a little bit

A bustling and sprawling marketplace for tourist curios, fruits and vegetables, household goods, meats and cheeses, condiments and baked goods. Very good people watching. There are two round buildings and then the usual mix of outdoor stalls. A very good selection of
Good place to go and get an idea of Tashkent daily life. Every kind of food on display and vendors of all kinds floating about.

The chorsu market of Tashkent is worth visiting , very well organized , relatively clean . lot of choice of Vegetables , mouth watering fruits, wide range dry fruits. Almonds , roasted peach seeds, Resins are worth carrying home. Few nice small Souvenirs and gold shops . We
Go to Chorsu bazaar, it's worthwhile. You can get all you want, be it only nice pictures or be it best bargains. You have ro make your own experience.
If you want it, you can probably find it at this market. Fresh produce, meat, dairy products, dried fruit and nuts, cooking oil, bread, clothes, etc...
My teenage son and I had a great afternoon exploring Chorsu. Don’t miss the bread area. Fresh hot local bread right out of the oven. Also, the so same here are the best in Tashkent!

If someone wants to buy something in Tashkent, that's the place. Clothing, household items, vegetables and fruit, breads and meats, arranged according to the subject in various compounds, the vast majority of which are covered by some kind of roof.. We enjoyed the complex of

You can buy almost anything at this market from bottles of saffron to hoarse meat. The various stalls are just fascinating to see what is for sale. The fruit stalls are very colourful as are the spice stalls. A really good market to come to and you can get a hot meal down the
A beautiful structure with different parts for Vegetables, meats and to others. Clean and well laid out. Value for money if you ar buying. Take 45 min to walk around.
Actually you can find everything here, from souvenirs to fresh fruits, cheese and meats, and also cooked food. Market is very clean, and prices are fair

Trying to describe this bazaar is quite easy if you've already been in Asia area. It is a mix of many differents things, from the smallest item you could look for your look going to the typical sweets you desire to get at noon...the food area on my personal opinion is the worth

Must go for spices and dry Fruits Bargaining is the norm here. However with prices being low it does not hurt to pay a few more som. It was quite hot in august even under the dome . I did not find many souvenir shops though.

Market that has everything (starting from groceries and ending by souvenirs). Can’t compare to other markets since haven’t been there. Bought some local dried fruits - very tasty. Can’t say it was cheap. Good place to see how locals do trade. Will definitely come again.

Chorsu Bazar is a must for everyone who enjoys the open markets, who wants to taste the real, authentic, local food and local fruits. The best apricots we ever had were the one we found here! We tried the somsa and we had lunch in the bazar, where the local chefs cook on the
I was there at the wrong time, about 2 in the afternoon, too hot to enjoy it much, it was a good place to get local souvenir.
Useless place. Only for below poverty line people. Oversold , not good quality of dry fruits.Get much better in India

We went there last month to buy dry fruits and bought a whole lot of them from different vendors as there are so many of them. Only after I got back did I realize that the quantities were far less actually. All the one kg packets ranged from 700-800 gm Buyers beware

Very good local market having daily use clothes, eatables, restaurant in open area, dry fruits etc. But it's small There are so many things which I couldn't explore because it was very hot during day time, Worth visiting
Nothing much to see there. Dont think it worth going there that much. Just go there if you have time or you never visit a fresh market.
Large indoor and outdoor market that is busy but safe. Fun to walk thru and see locals buying staples.

Chorsu Bazaar in Tashkent is a popular spot with locals and travellers alike. Cheap pricing for food, clothing, trinkets, all available for bartering too. We picked up some fruits, nuts and spices while we were here.

So enjoyable and fascinating at the same time , to visit this bazaar with its incredible variety of produce, spices, to " die " for , and the list goes on. Local people soooo receptive to my friend and I , having travelled so far for this experience. Definitely where you feel
If you are intending to buy clothes, shoes, food and ...... with cheaper prices then you must visit Chorsu. You will enjoy experiencing the tradition.

If you are an architecture buff than you should see this huge concrete and glass dome that covers the market hall. The market is on two levels and is spectacular. All kinds of stalls, from butchers to spices. If you want to buy nice raisins or sultana’s go upstairs.

This is a great place to buy fresh and dried fruits/nuts etc to take home. The different areas specialise in different products for example there are numerous bakeries, butchers, fruit and vegetable sellers etc The bazaar is very large with a great variety of choice and the

The bazar is quite huge and separated into different "topics". Assumingly if you need supplies you will have tons of opportunities. Of course this also is a huge tourist spot and many shopkeeper know it, so that many of them try to attrackt you. I personally am no friend of this
Its a very interesting place to visit and an easy way to get into the country reality. quite clean and organized place.

A proper bazaar with all sorts of different stuff. One part is currently under reconstruction, thus some entrances are filled with traders side by side. Feeling everything from hand-made exclusives to batteries and everyday items. The central dome is quite interesting,

This market is a great window into daily Uzbek life, people going about their daily business. The market has a huge range of very high quality and beautifully presented goods. The selection of food is amazing. Pick up some fresh bread, literally straight out of the brick oven,

This place could s big and the main hall is over two floors. Here you find fruit, veg, meat and yes also horse meat. On the upper floor dried fruit spices and all types of nuts. Amazing. Next to the main hall the market continues and offers many different products. Great picture
Huge space with hundreds of stalls selling mainly food items such as: dried fruits, nuts, spices, fresh poultry, meat, fruit and vegetables. Good opportunity to take some nice photos.

Chorsu is well worth a visit. It is subdivided in different parts, each with its own offering. The "meat section" in the big dome is amazing (though we doubt that the setting would pass the food safety tests of the EU). Nevertheless, it is a very interesting experience. Be

There was much anticipation of going to Chorsu bazar but quite frankly, it was a let down. The stuff on sale was mostly low quality, cheap knock offs... T-shirts, purses, track pants, sun glasses etc. The local souvenirs were interesting tho. Surprisingly the best part of

Made a quick stop at this market to try to look for some souvenirs. The market is split into different levels selling everything one can imagine. However, it’s too big and too repetitive with many vendors selling the exact same thing. Not a very pushy environment where vendors

The bazaar is worth visiting to experience local shopping. Under the main dome on the ground floor there is every type of meat you could imagine. Upstairs are the dried fruit & nuts. In a separate pavilion is the fruit & vegetables, all incredibly fresh.

After checking with the hotel we made our way by taxi to the Chorsu Bazaar. It is located on two sides of the road. There is one that is going down the steps to stalls, kiosks and shops of plants, fruits, vegetables, and also Uzbek handicrafts.....the second location across the

Chorsu bazaar is a fun place to visit to absorb the smells and sights. The first floor ( ground plus one) houses a bakery where you can see fresh bread being baked and indulge in a hot bread off the oven. Souvenirs are also available. Spend an hour or so here

Typical market on can find, selling fresh produces, meat, dry good. There is large section of the bazaar reserved for bakery, mainly bread they are tasteful, full of aroma. Note that there is no stall for fresh fishes, not sure I missed them. A good experience.

Myself and a friend visited on a weekday during our stay in Tashkent. The driver was able to park inside the gated area of the bazaar. I bought a traditional Uzbek hat, robe & belt for US$20. A friend bought a painting of Tashkent. The bazaar is so big we were not able to visit
This is a ‘must see’ in Tashkent. It is huge and incredibly clean. The fruit and vegetables looked delicious. Sellers display there wares beautifully and were all really friendly .

The place to visit in Tashkent. This place offers variety of choices from wet products to second hand items. Delicious and cheap local food. It’s a place where local people do their shopping and you’ll see local culture at its best.

We went to Chorsu several times. We loved the diverse products, the goods and the cultural experience. We bought food there and a few Uzbek pieces such as clothes to bread stamps to bring home. A must see if visiting and a must do if living in Tashkent.

This is where the locals come to shop. If you are looking for the typical souk type market or souvenirs, you will likely be disappointed. Although there are some “souvenirs” to be found (including some from others areas of Uzbekistan), they are mostly of the “made in China”

An original and authentic experience. Buy local almonds not to leave the place with empty hands. The most of the sellers are uzbek speaking only. Even knowledge of Russian doesn’t help in half of the bargaining cases
It's a good place to visit it's full of traditional Goods fruit snacks Herbst and a lot of interesting things to see

This bazaar has it all, people, traditional clothing, daily foods that the local eats (bread, meat, vegetables, dried fruits, nuts, spices), and many more. Be careful of pick-pocketing, put it in secure place, don't carry big bags. Better to have a local taking you there.

Chorsu is your place for souvenirs if in Tashkent, don't get confused with the dome markets in there as Chorsu is a bit close to the underground station where as most of the domes are meat selling shops which also come under Chorsu! People are real honest and friendly!

Wonderful place to see the food and wares of Uzbekistan. The fruit and vegetables are so vibrant, they look almost fake. Breads section is endless, with each vendor selling their own version of the local favorite. Great place to buy ceramics or embroidered items as well.

Just roam around the place for whatever you want. Pin to piano almost every thing available. Cost effective and many stalls available in market. One of the tourist attractions. Of course you can find this type of market (street market) in almost every country but this is worth

If you’ve never been to a bazaar before, then this might be interesting. It’s simply an open mall that sell cheap goods, nothing special other than it’s cheap and outdoors. One word of caution though: I found most of the outdoor food to be horrible, and the people coming around

Chorsu market is very interesting place. there you can not only see the appearance of endless rows with goods that are typical for Asia, but also a delicious snack. to visit Tashkent and not to go to Chorsu would be a mistake!
Huge local market where you can find anything! Dried fruits, fruits, vegetables, meat... all in a very local and authentic style, you can spend hours there! :)
A good place to see the locals way of living. Had a nice plov there. there is another bazaar on the right of the metro, which leads to Ko'kaldosh Madrassi
Our guide brought us to this bazaar. It has fruits, spices, crafts and other things to buy. Don't forget to negotiate prices.

I was very impressed by the organization and cleanliness of the bazaar even in the meat section . Excellent dried fruit and a bakery . Well worth a visit . No I've hassling you but as with any city in the world keep an eye on your wallet or handbag .
That is one not to miss. Huge area with all kinds of fresh food. Especially impressive is all the cheese and meat. Stunning and well worth a visit!

Always great to go see markets to better understand local culture. This market is in a 'modern' building but spills into many other areas. Segmented by good it's a really interesting visit. Butchery on ground floor, Dried fruit and nots above. The stall owners fully expect you

We browsed through the bazaar and were amazed at the variety of fresh produce,sweets, breads, etc that was available .a very colourful place to visit . The bakery was the highlight and the classic lepeshkas too tasty!
very cheap and colorful bazaar nuts was really cheap , also you can find traditional Ozbek staff , dont leave from bazaar before to eat Ozbek rise .. enjoy

The bazaar has many sections and its a huge place. Fruits, food, spices, clothes and whatever you need is available here. Its well organised i suppose but the lack of English speakers makes it difficult to convey one's needs. The food section has exotic stuff like horse meat
Shopping from Chorsu Bazaar was like revisiting in History. Typical street market where you can buy almost anything.

The bazaar was highly recommended by the hostel that we stayed in but really is more a place for those who live in Tashkent to buy their food and other needed items than for tourists to purview, there are some slightly touristy stalls but not many.

This is not for beginners. Take good care of your belongings and bargain your way through the selection of foods and goods. Touting can be a bit annoying but nothing unusual. Scams are not uncommon but the experienced traveller has no problems identifying them. Maybe not the

This is a great local market where the people of Tashkent convene to either sell their wares or buy their groceries. The market is organized by the type of item being sold. There are separate sections for fruit, vegetables, meats, nuts, and then there is a less-organized flea

I bought some good quality embroidered goods here (accompanied by a specialist) and enjoyed the hustle and bustle of the place at the same time. There was also a travelling performing circus group there when I visited - pulling cars and doing gymnastics

We shopped for all manner of nuts at the bazaars of Samarkand and Bukhara, but wished we'd done it all at Chorsu in Tashkent, where the prices we were able to haggle were the best, and the quality was just as good or better than at any of the others.
Dirty, crowded, hot, stinky (in places), full of stuff you don't need - in other words a perfect Central Asian bazaar.

Big and nice orient Bazaar A lot of fruits and vegetables you can buy some nuts and dried fruits A large pavilion for meat and dairy products There is also a orient carpets area enjoy warning ! Beware of pickpockets :-)
Depends what you are looking for, this can be interesting experience, but be ready for bit Chaotic and lot of people

A great place to explore. Lots of interesting booths with some things that will be immediately familiar to Western travelers, and many things that will seem strange. It is also a great place to change money and strike up a conversation. We even watched a slack line gymnast

Very disappointing if you're looking for the typical souk/bazaar type environment. Downstairs are a couple of touristy shops..a large biscuit/sweets/random things shop. Around the outside.... gold shops and 'made in china' rubbish. The only interesting part is the market

Actually went there twice. Interesting place and gives a real feel for life in Uzbekistan. There is a large covered open air restaurant where you can order food. It is a nice place to relax with good food and rub elbows with the locals. English speaking Uzbek's more than
Must visit place, crowded, dirty, loud and charming at once. You may buy cheap souvenirs, textile etc.
This market is clean and well sorted for meat, spices, nuts, vegetables, fruits etc, but there is nothing really special about it. Prices are the same as in all other markets

Wide, two-ways streets. Pompous, monumental architecture of the government buildings. Over-designed parks and squares. That is Tashkent (re-built after a terrible earthquake of 1966) shown to tourist. Go to Chorsu bazaar and see the real world of local people. Meats (horse

Now this is a place to visit. From the horsemeat butchers and walk-in bakeries with their clay ovens, to the long aisles of dried fruit and spice stalls, from the expansive food courts to the silk clothing and carpet shops, it's well worth immersing yourself in real-life

Okay so if it's your first market in Uzebkistan you will enjoy it but if you did it in Samarkand avoid this. It's the same. Spices, toys, carpets, handicrafts, bread, meat. It's amazing for the first timer and for people used to controlled markets abroad. Here there are smells
All kind of breads, meats, vegetables and delicious street food. From samosa, dumplings -nd some other food I cannot remember name to shaslik. A must.

You can find here everything for every taste. There is a section for every food, every spice, every type of clothing, etc. There are many prepared food stalls, where you can have your shishlik, kebab or laghman meat-and noodle soup.
Thus place is very cheap for tourists. You can find a lot of souvenirs and dry fruits. Good service and too easy to find

Heard so much about it. Frankly speaking its nothing but an ordinary arabic style 'haat'. Crawford market of Mumbai is far more superior. फूल of Cheap, chinese stuff from jackets to jeans, shoes, bags and more. Generally Local people come for shopping and foreigners as a part of

Chorsu bazaar is the place where you get full imagination of everyday life of local people. In a big blue dome in the center of the bazaar, you can find all kinds of dry fruits, spices and outside to the north you can find a line of handicraft masters shops where they sell

azaar is the heart of every oriental city, the center of public life, breadwinner of the whole city. Since the dawn of time bazaars appeared on the intersections of trade roads, on big squares of cities. They played role of main places of the city, where merchants, traders and
Best place is Chorsu market is circle indoor market, where selling dry fruits, meat and etc. Outdoor is typical for Central Asia markets.

A very good bajar where you can purchase all most all of the things of your need starting from food to cosmetic followed by kitchen items to cloth. Price are also reasonable. Sometimes you need to bargain to get a good price.

This market is only a typical muslim bazaar market containing shops and stalls selling local fruits, food, spice, and other Chinese made products. Compared with bazaar in other countries like Morocco, Turkey, and Iran, this market is much less interesting to walk around and see

The market area is quite big, so if you think you haven't found what you are looking for, most probably you have missed some pavilion. This is the place where to buy everything, but as a foreigner I put the most emphasis on nuts, dried fruits, fresh fruits and spices. You will
You can buy a lot of interesting things from this market but you have to take care to the price. They ask for 350000 and you can have it for 200000 only...

We went here on our last day in Tashkent to buy some snacks and souvenirs from nearby shops. The market has a wide selection of fruit, nuts, other nibbles, bread, meat etc etc. It is new and not of any historical interest.

I have seen lots of bazaars and I think this one is over estimated by tourists. Ok they have lots of fresh vegy, nuts, dried fruits and meat sections. ( where you can buy horse meat btw) I think nothing special. Anyway here are the pictures

It was just ok. There are many vendors selling all the same stuff. The people are not pushy and the items are nice but it not something that impressed This should be seen but do not think it will rock your world. Oh and go when it is warm.

This market in Tashkent is spread on a large area with all in one place. It has different sections for food, vegetables / fruits, dry-fruits ( dome ), cloths, chocolates etc. At entrance you will find many local currency exchangers. After bargain, They will give you good rate

With a huge variety of different types of items - right from the smallest to the costliest things of day to day utility at home , traditional artefacts, embroidered handbags, purses, slippers ,shoes, caps, dresses for men ,women and children, kitchenware,bedlinen etc.I mean you

text.quote: This traditional yellow-brick madrassa was built in the 16th century by the Shaybanid Dynasty.
trip: The Kukeldash Madrasah is not the best mosque in Uzbekistan (though given its challengers, there is no shame in being unable to achieve that title) but it’s a very beautiful complex and is incredibly serene inside. Despite being right next to a main road, stepping into the
This lovely medieval madrasah is just near the Chorsu Market. It is one of the few buildings that survived the 1966 earthquake.
Peaceful courtyard and a glimpse of Tashkent's past. The staff were very friendly and eager to talk about the history of this building.
Great place to visit. Steeped in so much history, a must for people who like to venture into the past.
While visiting the Chorsu Bazaar, we stopped by here. There is an Entrance Fee even to go into the Courtyard. It is located next to the Dzhuma Mosque.

A madrasah has been here for centuries, but the original building suffered from wear and tear, and during the Soviet period was put to other uses. It has been beautifully restored and is now a functioning madrasah again. The clean, carefully redecorated look may not be

The original Madrasah was built in 1570 but has undergone various demolitions and renovations over the years.It also has had various uses from a museum and back to a Madrasah. Worthy of a look if at the Chorzu Market as it is close to the Metro Station.

Kukeldash Madrasah is situated just walking distance from Chorsu bazaar and was built in 1570 by the Shaybanid Dynasty of rulers .This was one of the few religious buildings that survived the 1966 Tashkent Earthquake which destroyed almost the entire city.The madrasah is built

Place is quite nice, there is a lot of grass, but the security guard is rude. I've just wanted to make few photos and he started screaming I have to pay for entrance. I was trying to explain that I do not want to go inside the mosque - I would like to make few photos - but he
Took a stroll from the chorhsu bazaar and arrived at this madrasah. Was nice and the gatekeeper was nice enough to let us take a look around the school. Entrance fee is required.

Visted this beautiful madrassa today. I was built as a Madrassa and then was converted into a caravan serai in the 18th century, then it served as a fortress. In the 20th century it was a museum, first of atheism, and later of folk music. In the 1990s, the building was made a
It is best to have a guide take you around here. The architecture and history is fantastic. So much to see and photograph.
Another jewel around Chorsu Bazar , the edifice grabs eyeballs from far. The blue tiles and the intricate work are beautiful.
There are some fabuloud building here to look at and take many photos of. The history of the place is worth while listening from your guide.
Uzbekistan is full of history and this restored Madrassah is a good example of that. I recommend it.
A working madrasa with a nice garden inside, definitely worth a visit. Plus, it is located near Chorsu bazaar, so makes it a good combo.
Compared to other spots in Uzbekistan, Kukeldash is not really a highlight. We passed it while strolling around in Chorsu bazar and the market.
The madrasah has a gorgeous interior, with a lovely garden. Outside the tiles are in disrepair in a few places; however you can still get good photos. It is a short walk from the Chorsu Bazaar.
This is a good example of a standard Medressa. It's near the Chorsu Market, the traditional Uzbek market for locals. You can visit this place first before entering the market area.
Very interesting place, especially since madrasah is still in use- people take lessons about islam there. You can also see some artwork and arabic calligraphy.

If you visit chorsu bazaar this place is just 10min of walking away. Its quite nice but don't expect it to be like Samarkand or Bukhara...but it gives you a good impression what you are going to see on your onward journey. Prices are acceptable and the garden inside is a very
The madrasa is located near the bazaar Chorsu and it is one of the scools where the students are learning the religion. I prefer not to go inside in order not to disturb the students studying in it.
We enjoyed visiting this interesting place in Tashkent. We also visited the Romanov Palace and Amir Timur Statue in the middle of the roundabout

This very old madrasa is the main attraction for tourist interested in history of Central Asia. it is located close to the MRT station, and very close to the traditional market. If you are not planning visiting Samarkand or Bukhara then this is a must to see.
Kukeldash medressa is situated next to chorus market , just watched it from outside but the beauty is just awsum . I would definitely go next time if I get a chance to visit this place
Nice and historical for Tashkent. Nothing special if compared to Bukhara and Samarkand. Near Chorsu Bazaar and Chorsu metro station. Did not go inside, but looked at it from outside.

Build in the 16th century as Islamic school, went through a lot of changes and damaged by earthquakes. The place lay in ruins until mid 20th century, when it was restored very tastefully. The garden in the interior part of the central building is very tranquil and nurtured. It

This was the first Madressa we saw in Uzbekistan and we were impressed. In comparison with the Madressa of Samerkand the one in Tashkent is not very interesting. It is not worth going to the Kukeldash Medressa, if you have already seen many extremely beautiful Medressa in Khiva,
It is now a working Medressa but has been used for many purposes over the centuries. It has ben heavily restored in the 20th century. A lovely building a weel worth spending some time here.

It is a working medressa and nect to Chorsu Bazaar. So why not visiting once at a time. Visit this medressa in the afternoon, then go to Chorsu Bazaar and then have your osh (pilav) in Chorsu Bazaar and after doing your shopping for fruits and salads go to your home.

The best of the mosaics in this worldi are in Muslim mosques and this is lovely. Multiple buildings in this complex (medressa is a school) include a Koran (the oldest in the world) from 700 AD

text.quote: Monumental square with fountains & esplanades around an equestrian statue of 1300s ruler Timur.
trip: This is a pretty big square with a statue of Amir Temur in the centre if the square which is great as a photo stop.

Amir Timur Square (Amir Temur xiyabani) is a central square in the Uzbek capital Tashkent. The square was created in 1882 and it received several names during its time, until the square was named after Tamleran / Timurs after independence from the Soviet Union. In the middle of
Nice place to visit. It’s a square which is located right across Hotel Uzbekistan & a short walk away from a Mall.

It's impossible to be in Tashkent and not come across with the central square of Amir Timur. A very big statue of the king adorns the square. It is a place with a lot of locals and tourists pouring in and taking a lot of photos.
Though I visited after dawn but still it's worth a million to visit. Faboulas place to roam around.. I felt that Its cosy for teenagers and history revisit for aged people. I enjoyed both I e
It’s beautiful with wide landscaped roads and foot paths. It’s an important junction. During your stay one would cross this many times.

Tashkent feels incredibly calm and peaceful in any case, but Amir Timur square feels especially so. The park is beautiful and well kept, and the statue of Timur set against the backdrop of the Hotel Uzbekistan gives a real sense of the old and the new in contrast. You can’t go
Well manicured gardens and the Uzbekistan hotel in the backdrop plus a new conference building make the whole area very picturesque
This is a monumental square with fountains, and walking boulevards around the statue of the 13 Century Mongol warlord Amir Timur.

If you go during the day at the weekend, you might see families with their sons in military uniform taking photographs here. Amir Temur was/is Uzbekistan's hero from history, and they clearly still honour him.
Gives a great glimpse of the past life! A lovely stroll in the evening in a well maintained garden with glimpses of so many buildings all around it. A must do.

Travelled through the square during October and it was wonderful. The vibrancy of the place, it felt good to be here. Behind the statue lays the hotel Uzbekistan, the same one I watched on television when watching Race Across The World. Later on the place lit up and it looked

It was a nice square, with an imposing statue of Tamerlane or Amir Temur as he is known locally, on horseback, apparently one of 3 of him throughout the city. It was a pleasant stroll through the gardens surrounding it and the city of Tashkent in general.

The Amir Timur Square is a must visit in Tashkent. It is probably easiest reached by bus 33, 38, 51 and 67 which run to the Square. The subway is a popular option, as two lines intersect at the Amir Temur Hiyoboni (red line) and Yunus Rajabiy (green line) stations. These
I never knew that Amir Temur was a major figure in Uzbek history until now. It was great to see a memorial dedicated to his legacy.
This place is surrounded by amazing buildings and the way Statue is positioned it is a really ideal place to create a selfie memory.

The Amir Temur Square is in a large green park with some notable buildings surrounding it - Uzbekistan Hotel and Amir Timur Museum. Broadway Alley, a pedestrian street is also nearby. There is a large statue of Amir Temur in the square. This place is definitely a must visit

This area of Tashkent is a must-read for fans of Soviet-era architecture. The monumental modernist behemoth of the Hotel Uzbekistan was the highlight for us. This thing is a superb example of modernist architecture with a curving facade decorated with elaborate fretwork. The
An easy walk from Independence square and surrounded by large gardens. The statue is well crafted and captures the pride and power of Timur.

The statue of Amir Temur is majestic and stands in the center of the square. It looks splended with Hotel Uzbekistan in the background. A good place to stop for a while and take some photos and nice place to go aorund for a stroll after dinner in the night. Many people around in

Then main attraction is the equestrian statue of Timur, which is pretty huge (like several others in Uzbekistan). It is a magnet for all sorts of people, including local youth, and is nicely set in gardens. Adjacent is the magnificent (if you like Soviet style) Hotel Uzbekistan

Amir Timur Square has a equestrian bronze statue of Amir Timur in the centre with fountains and small trees around the statue.The Square is surrounded with buildings of the “Uzbekistan” Hotel, University of Law (former Women’s Gymnasium), the Amir Timur Museum and well-known

The statue is in the middle of a small park which offers lots of benches to rest tired feet, there is limited shade, the heat can be draining. The statue is impressive, the plinth had a number of 'occupants' over the years who disappeared as the political landscape changed. The

It is said he saw himself as the heir to Genghis Khan and from all accounts, Amir Tamir, who was born in what is Uzbekistan today in 1336, pulled together numerous countries by force or personality from the Med. to India and formed a vast Central Asian empire that included
Easily spotted by the huge horse and rider, this monument marks the area celebrating the emblem of the country of Uzbekistan. It is a good photo spot with the Museum and Hotel Uzbekistan nearby
Central square with the famous statue of Tamburlaine in the centre of well laid out paths and gardens. Overlooked by the soviet-style hotel Uzbekistan

Our guide gave us a great perspective on what happened there years and years ago. The place is part of the new Tashkent, and build by the Russians. The statue was replaced a few times until they gained their independence in 1991. This statue represents Uzbekistan, and the people
it is just a statue. Not much to it. Right in front of the Hotel Uzbekistan. It is ok statue, in a park area which can be accessed by underground pass to cross the road.

This is a really nice square with a great mix of old style soviet architecture, with the overpowering Hotel Uzbekistan, meeting the newer build style of post communist era architecture with big strong marble style buildings. It's in the centre of Tashkent so worth a stroll
Lovely place, nice gardens and of course, Amir Temur. Very centrally located and on a hot day, a nice place to rest with an ice cream...
We took the metro to get here and then enjoyed walking around the park. The statue of Amir Temur on his horse is very impressive. The park is good for bird watching.
Amir Temur is central to the history of this region, so it was really good to see a statue of him on my first day. Its a reasonably pretty square so nice to have a sit in and people watch.
Very nice setup, beautiful parc with a link to a great history. A must to visit and learn about the history of the region.
Worth walking through and finding out about your history. Not much else really but go and see hotel Uzbekistan nearby!
Spent an entire afternoon here just taking in the sights, talking to the locals and taking nice pictures of the uzbekistal hotel right across the road.
Tashkant The Amir Temur Square is big and beautiful square, a very big statue of Amir Temur in the square, very impressive, we drove through it many times.
It is a very good place to spend an hour or two with your friends. Also has some history behind, obviously.

A large park just in the center of town Very well designed and wonderful landscape gardening. Clean and regular streets, nice cafe shops and restaurants are offering extraordinary choices for fun. Arcade behind the garden is full of entertainments. You will have wonderful time

A must see square in Tashkent with a park all around. it's located in the middle of a massive roundabout, which hardly has cars driving in it. Great to sit on a bench and look at all the flowers, trees and other tourists

The location is the best thing about this square as you are surrounded by some impressive buildings. The opera building is the obvious one, but the Hotel Uzbekistan is really impressive as well. Free to visit.

This is the main square of Tashkent, and it is a lovely park but it has one disappointing feature: almost no shade, and it can be hot here (it was 90 Fahrenheit in May!). The park is planted mostly with evergreen trees which are useless for shade. Someone told us that it used to

I love visiting this square full of green areas and benches. The contrast between temur statue, hotel Uzbekistan and the building makes a great pictures as it put together the evolution of this country thru the years. It can be quite crowded on Saturdays afternoons.

The first thing that strikes you when you drive around the Square is the open spaces, manicured lawns and the imposing International Convention Centre with the Hotel Uzbek as the backdrop. If you have time, you can stroll around the Square which is lined by acres of flower beds
A really nice place to see. Scenery is awesome if looking from the bar on the top of the Uzbekistan hotel.
The pride of Uzbekistan- history meets modern history with architecture around it. Good photography spots

Historical place in the downtown of Tashkent. Very, clean, green and accurate for having a walk. When you get off at the Amir Temur Square station of Tashkent Underground and pass through the pedestrian subway and you will be in the Amir Temur Square. In front of you will see

It is an enormous square, rounded by important buildings, extremely clean , peaceful. Do not miss Amir Temur Museum nearby, where you can start to understand better the history of Uzbekistan and the heritage left by the powerful leader ( known as Timur Lenk or Tamerlan, both
Really nice park with monument of Amir Temur. Very nice clean and peaceful place in center of Tashkent.

Amir Timur Square was another popular spot with the locals in the evening with its spacious area. With a number of museums and dining establishments circling its perimeter, it’s really an unmissable area as all the main streets converge here. The statue of Timur at the center
Its a really nice square, close to a metro station (A.Timur Hiyoboni). With Uzbekistan Hotel on the back and a pedestrian street in front of the big statue. Dont misst it !
Very nice pretty statute of taimur , located on the taimur square in front of the Taimu musem.you cannot miss this while passing by from car.

History and dignity all together to reveal the past of a society. You feel different when you are around the Amir Temur's statue and the square. There is also a museum there. The hotel Uzbekistan is very close and food etc is cheap there
This is what would qualify as the city center I suppose. There is a big statue of Amir Timur in the middle. There are benches all around, it is a popular place for couples to canoodle.
This is a nice area to go visit there are some very nice hotels around and some other places to walk around and see
Can’t miss it, at the center of Tashkent. Great statue of Amir temur. Can’t miss the iconic hotel Uzbekistan
Best place for visiting And to be honest very busy place. Alot of visitors are almost there everytime i visit there
The statue of Taimurlane on a horse is impressive . It was a cold winter day but the sun was out so I basked in the sun on a bench watching people go by.
The very center of the city. Nice view, here you can find Amir Temur's statue. Here you can have a rest enjoing trees and green.
A haven of peace in the middle of a busy city. Great statue of Amir Timur on horseback which sets the place off, but the flowers, shrubs and gardens make this place special
Amir Temur Square, with the statue of Amir Temur riding on a horse, is a landmark of Tashkent. You should not miss the museum of the same name, located on this square.
Tghis is just another square decotated to the famous Amir Timur. Just walk around the square as there is not much else to do.

It is a very nice square including the Broadway area (starting opposite to Amir Temur Statue) which is where many locals hangout after sunset to walk or sit. Includes local playing music, selling paintings and kid activities. Among my fave hangouts in Tashkent!!

A very pleasant park you can view in 10 minutes. Stay longer if you want to zone out. There is a good place to eat grilled chicken at the Tashkent Law University building.
A beautiful green square close to the metro for easy access and a nice place to sit and talk to people.

Good location for walking around, famous for local young guys who play music, dance and just walk in the square. Found some small shops with souvenirs. Hookah place, Italian ice cream, sushi bar. Recommended :)
Uzbekistan people feel very proud of it. Huge space dotted with beautiful green spaces and open spaces. Good for photography and relaxing for few hours. Must visit

So clean city and organized! There were policemen in the streets making sure everything is safe and it felt safe! People were willing to help us around with finding places. We took taxi which was very cheap.

Managed to get there easily by a metro. This is a landmark sight no one should miss visiting Tashkent. The photo of the monument together with Hotel Uzbekistan is a must. Precaution to have a sunscreen protection as there is not much shade.

Its a very memorable place to share the memorable experience with family and friends to share. Reflecting a very excellent civil work of Old Uzbekistan History. Very much spacious and with well organised Flower Plant Gardens and structures to enjoy and memorise.

Amber temur square is located in the city center here you can see the statue of Amir temur riding horse with view of hotel Uzbekistan in the background and also surrounded with a nice park you should visit this place if you’re in Tashkent

I can recommend to visit the park, but not because there is the special sight or similar, but because it is nice, relaxing and it makes fun to watch the people. The statue and buildings around probably are somehow attractive and this is the prestige place, but thats it. Anyways
great palce to spend some time wandering around, not only at the statue & its near around, but also to walk around the adjacent parks & walkways & nearby mosque.

it was very impressive… all around was very clean… designed very good… connected with a park to walk around...

It's alright. Just a statute in the middle of the a small square. You can walk around the, but it isn't much to see.

A well maintained and pleasant location with an impressive statue of Temur. I walked here on a Saturday evening with my hosts. I was struck by the lack of people around and about on a Saturday evening. Otherwise, this was a pleasant venue for a short (30 minute) visit.
It is just a normal square where you can find a bank with an ATM, but there is nothing really interesting about it. You can just pass by, but you won't spend many hours around.

Located not far from Metro Amir Timur. Here you can see the locals strolling around, and some will even talk to you to practice their English. Further west is the famous Broadway, where a lot of souvenirs and art works are selling there. At night, there are also restaurants and
amazing work done by govt. who properly maintained the tourist spots, friendly people who don't know proper English but they help an unknown person.

Must see sight with Tamarlane's statue, surrounded by clock towers. Several fountains and pretty gardens.
It is one of the important tourist spot in Tashkent.. Amir Temur is the most revered personality in Uzbekistan. The square was quite big and garden surrounding the statue was in excellent condition.
Another square with a statue and might be of interest to history lovers. Not really a must see, but there is only that much that one can do in Tashkent, so you might as well check it out .
The park of Amir Temur was created in the end of the 19th century and deserves paying a visit. you can visit it while using a metro, or while visiting the Place of Independance.
Nice place to walk around, especially from here to the Independence Square, passing the A. Navoi Theatre and the Romanov Palace.
Large square. I would recommend the restaurant at the top floor at Hotel Uzbekistan, to get a great view over Amir Temur Square.

Nice park with Amir Taimur's monument, good place to take a relaxing walk and enjoy the serenity with the once soviet time classic Uzbekistan hotel in the background,
Love this walk.roads so clean and shaded.safe to walk anytime.total consideration for pedestrians.very aesthetically done

Beautifully maintained by women who sweep the paths and also by students seen weeding the flower beds. Apparently university students have to do voluntary work one day a month to maintain the appearance of their city. An idea which should be copied!

Its a nice and clean place with historical value. Visit during evening time to get best pictures and peaceful time.

A beautiful museum with many antique items used by the great personalities of yore --dresses , utensils , crockery ,weapons , paintings ,art pieces & a lot more.Sufficient to provide knowledge of the times. A place worth visiting !!!

The Amir Temur's Square is a nice place for having a good time. You can walk in a beautiful garden or just sit on a bench talking with friends. There also a great statue of a national hero Amir Temur.

Amir Temur Square is a nice place to see, with a statue of Amir Temur in the center. It has been maintained nicely. Not crowded at all, and is at walkable distance from Broadway street or from your hotel, nearby.

Amir Temur Square is centrally located in Tashkent. There is a park which is cleanly maintained. You can have a nice view of Amir Temur Statue, with the Uzbekistan Hotel and a Government Building as a background.

Very pleasant square reached by an underpass with an informal market and lots of green. The statue in the centre is impressive and the square is very well maintained. Great for people watching and they are all very friendly.
stauten amazing never forgettable very beautiful place with madrasas archaeology , climate, the cuting of wall.

This is one of the most beautiful places in Tashkent. The park is big, clean and people are really nice. You can have a nice view of Amir Temur Statue, with the Uzbekistan Hotel and a Government Building as a background.
You must come here to realize what Amir temur means for Uzbekistan and its history. You will enjoy the greenery as well the statue.
