Subscribe today
In a typical planetarium theatre, programs—commonly called sky shows—are offered to the public on a regular schedule. Show themes may focus on straightforward astronomical and space topics or take up related issues such as the cosmologies of ancient cultures, the extinction of the dinosaurs, or the future of life on Earth. The trend, especially for large audiences and multiple daily shows, is toward total computer automation of the program, combining visual display, cued music and sound effects, and prerecorded narration. Large planetariums with technologically advanced multimedia installations often supplement their science programs with shows featuring pure entertainment based on light, video, and music. In significant ways, in both technology and public program content, the distinction has lessened between planetarium theatres and other giant-screen “total immersion” entertainment centres.When the Deutsches Museum’s planetarium, featuring the Zeiss projector, was publicly unveiled in 1923 (two years before the museum’s formal opening), it was described as a “schoolroom under the vault of the heavens.” Special educational sky shows for schoolchildren remain an essential part of the program in most installations; astronomy lectures are given to college classes; and the facilities are commonly used for courses or lectures in adult continuing-education programs.The term planetarium was originally used to describe a type of mechanical model designed to portray the orbital motions of the planets and their moons. Made for teaching and exhibition, such tabletop devices consisted of small globes, representing the Sun and planets, that were mounted on wire rods supported and geared at a central pedestal. Many included the major moons known at the time of construction. Also called orreries (after the English sponsor of one built in 1712), they could be quite elaborate and accurate.

It’s a walking street with plenty of activity. Music, performers, kiosks, cafes, bars, restaurants name it and it’s all there. Popular hang out for the youngsters.
This street was very busy when we visited, lots of food stalls, amusement activities and artists selling things. We just happened upon it on our evening stroll.
Saligokh Street is a pedestrian street near the Amir Timur Square. While we were there, it was a Saturday and there were a lot of families and kids. There were some booths for games for the kids.

This area is made of 2 streets perpendicular to each other, both pedestrianised: Sayligokh and Broadway. Saligokh is for kids and the young at heart, lined mostly with amusement stalls, but interestingly, with pin pong tables at the western end. The cross street (Broadway) is

text.wiki:
Ilkhom Theatre (Ильхом Театр Марка Вайля) is a theatre company based in Tashkent, Uzbekistan. Founded by Mark Weil (Марк Яковлевич Вайль) in 1976, it was the first independent theatre in the Soviet Union, and remains self-supporting to this day.Weil was murdered in September 2007.  His last production was the Greek tragedy The Oresteia; despite his murder the day before it was scheduled to open, the actors went ahead because, according to them and to Mark Weil, the show must go on.In 2011 Ilkhom Theatre won one of the Prince Claus Awards.

text.wiki:
Kosmonavtlar is a space-programme-themed station of the Tashkent Metro on Oʻzbekiston Line which was opened on 8 December 1984 partly in honour of cosmonaut Vladimir Dzhanibekov. 
Column-type station with two underground vestibules.
The architectural decoration of the station on the theme of space. The interior is decorated with blue ceramic medallions with images of Ulugbek, Icarus, Valentina Tereshkova, Yuri Gagarin, Vyacheslav Volkov and Vladimir Dzhanibekov. The ceiling resembles the Milky Way, which shone glass stars. Travel wall platform floor-to-ceiling windows throughout the length of the platform is gradually moving from azure to dark blue, recalling the atmosphere of the Earth. Round tower platform covered with glass, and metal, granite and marble-trimmed lobbies stations, lobbies finish is, as the station, on the theme of space exploration.

Clean. Quiet. Do not take excessive baggage. No bathrooms. More security in Metro than at the White House.
Nice stations FAst moving escalators and trains You can't take photos there as it was a Bomber shelter Recommended Hold on tight when train starts or you will be grown back

Once you get the hang of it travelling on the Metro to various Tashkent destinations is pretty good and very cheap. Be prepared to have your back pack examined by the police/military on duty and remember a smile and a greeting go a long way.

Very cheap and reliable way of transportation but might be slower than taxis and doesn't cover the whole city though it goes to the main touristic sites and city centre.

Just sorry I couldn't take any photos to share with family and friends. A must see if you are in Tashkent
Metro is veru beautiful. But some stations need a bit renovation. And also sometimes you have to wait for the train up to 10 minutes.
Amazing soviet architecture and decoration. The metro ride is nice, and the stations are really clean.
Amazing .Very nice and good and safety confor transport. I would like used this for all times. I think is one of the best metro of the Soviet Union and very useful.

Interesting side trip. Well worth the time. It can be a little busy on occasions. Good photo opportunity.

Tashkent metro is really a wonderful part of the city. Clean, piece, fast, cheap and the amazing stations designed in national and modern style. one gets on Tashkent metro not only to get somewhere but to enjoy its attractive stations. I like it.

its very convenient to use the tickets are very cheap like 40 us cents. staions are grand and clean , and its better than the subway in nyc hands down !!!

text.wiki:
Chorsu is a station of the Tashkent Metro on Oʻzbekiston Line which was opened on 6 November 1989. 
The walls of the vestibule and the platform decorated with white Gazgan marble floor station is covered with gray granite.
The station is decorated with bas-reliefs of "Ecology" and Link of Times (painter Kim Yu).


== References ==
trip: This is a very large market with open air stalls, and some in closed areas, with everything from shoes to children's items to food to everything in between. I went with an item in mind and found it - although it took about 15 minutes of looking. Don't buy at the first stalls at
Unfortunately, the place was more than dirty. It was stinky actually!!! Meat was thown everywhere around and the smell was awfull!!! I was so disapointed when visited this place.
Too large to see everything...! As I came in December, I could see unusual marchandise: someone sell potatoes on truck. If you go there, recommend to have a brief plan :)

Chorsu is the central market of Tashkent. The locals do their shopping here but the place can be interesting for someone visiting the city. The interior section is majestically big and there are a few nice shops for handicrafts. The prices are lower than the ordinary tourist
Local market mostly crowded with locals. Of you do not have dry fruit shopping, can be avoided......
Had heard so much about this place that we were rather disappointed. The stores were mediocre and the goods of a very average quality.
The chorsu is the biggest market area I have ever seen. You can find everything in this bazaar but it is really chaotic place.

Chorsu Bazaar feels incredibly authentic, and is like nothing you’ll see in the West. Truthfully, I didn’t find any of the things on offer particularly appealing (and the stuff on sale for tourists isn’t particularly exciting), but the whole draw of Chorsu Bazaar for me are the
This covered bazaar is wonderful to stroll through, especially the nut, fruit and vegetable sections where the produce looks fabulous. We did not find the clothing and souvenir stalls enticing.
Nice traditional bazaar with all the hustle and bustle of a bazaar. A variety of food and other items available
A must if you want to see a glimpse of everyday life. Good place to get cheap items (snacks and trinkets). Make sure to get a meal at the row of open air restaurants - really good stuff there.

Classic veg/meat/fruits/spices/ all kinds of household stuff market for locals. Tourists get charged at least 10times the price the locals get, no matter how you bargain, they rather won't sell than give you a reasonable price. Not worth the journey from the other side of the

I visited the market twice, once for looking and the other to buy a bag to take back Uzbek crafts. The market is a site to see and fun, especially in the food sections (for foodies like me). My bag ended up being barely strong enough to carry my stuff back to Canada so be

Worth a visit . I can’t say more . Prices vary if you can bargain your good . The place is good for understanding how much meat and cheese Uzbek people eat. One of the biggest meat and cheese markets Ive seen in my life . Outside the market its very big and you can find

We came to Chorsu Bazaar on a Sunday around noon. The Chorsu metro can also get you here. The market is large. There are sections for meats, fruits and vegetables. If you go to the 2nd floor, you can get an overview of the entire area. If you exit the round dome building,

A very large, confusing area with hundreds (thousands?) of vendors selling a huge variety of things. At its centre is a domed indoor market selling meat, cheese and (upstairs) a vast array of nuts and dried fruits. Perfect for your last day in Tashkent when you're hoping to buy

One of the few 'Must sees' in Tashkent and it is worth it. It is very much a working market and thankfully not touristifyed. You need small denomination of som just in case! Great variety of produce, no hassle. Great to see bread being made -every tourist must be brought to see

We went on Sunday - a bad day to visit, lots and lots of people! There is so much stuff there, for everyone’s taste. My absolute favorite were nuts - I love nuts, and there are so many to choose from! I also enjoyed the spices, vegetables, and various salads. And, of course,

No visit to Tashkent can be complete without spending a few hours in Chorsu. Its scale and spread are mind-blowing! Flowers, fruits, meats, dry fruits, bread, clothes, bags, souvenirs, bakery, local food, salads, whatever you can imagine is available. The most remarkable

Chorus Bazaar is a sprawling indoor and outdoor market which seems like Central Asia's answer to Bangkok's Chatachak Market. For dedicated market enthusiasts, this one will deliver, as it offers everything from gold to terracotta and cashews to silk. We are not keen shoppers,
Visited twice the bazar . I did most of my shopping from Chorsu Bazar. Best place to buy dry fruits , fresh Uzbek Bread . Tasty local food .

Chorsu bazaar is the biggest market place of Tashkent. You will get everything here right from souvenirs, handicrafts, crockeries, fruits, vegetables, nuts, dryfruits, milk products, local cuisines, restaurants, money exchange and a metro station too which opens right in the

My can driver was butt and dropped me off a block away across the street but friendly locals got me to the right place. The place is huge. People are hustling and selling and negotiating all over the place. Do not ever pay full price. Cut in half and negotiate. Here is English

Charsu is a huge bazaar that sells everything from exotic meats and fruits to handy crafts and many will enjoy a treasure hunt in it's vast streets and enclaves. It was not my cup of tea as I could not stand the smell of meat, or the chaos that surrounds it. But I probably paid

The Chorsu Bazaar provided a look at how the local people in Tashkent live. Access is via the Metro and ext at Chorsu Station.The market was full of people and had atmosphere and was clean and neat and well organized.You will find everything you need here and some things you do

chorrsu bazar in tashkent is a small world in itself here you will find local people and tourists purchasing dryfruits vegetalbles and gifts and stationery items THE bazar gives you a feeling of the old world charm with a lot of bargaining to purchase your required items
The smells, the food, the people, just the whole place in general is fantastic! There are so many different vendors showcasing their local goods. An absolute must do while in Tashkent!
The bazar was a centre of old Tashkent and as the name suggests it is circular complex with entry from all four sides. Go shopping for local dry fruits and fresh fruits

Recommended for all travelers who would like to obtain souvenirs, National jewelry, carpets , clothes and many other things. Inexpensive bazaar! Kindly recommend for travelers to go there with the local friends in order to avoid highly offered prices by shopkeepers:)) anyways,

This is a must see in Tashkent. Could be seen multiple times because the make up of the vendor's stalls and the expressions on the people's faces changes often. Be prepared for a sensory overload and remember the entrance so you can find your way back out because there is

A nice place to visit since it provides safe, enjoyable and economic tourism. Hotels, food and transport are cheap. History and monuments are impressive. People are excellent and hospitable. Dry fruits are must purchase. The value for money spent is high.
Great place to bargain for dry fruits and to roam around to get a feel of the bazaar style haggling of times gone by.

The Chorsu Bazaar in Tashkent is an interesting market for all sorts of products ranging from vegetables, soveniors, food and various other items. One section that was particularly interesting was the bread section where bakers bake bread in huge clay ovens and one can buy them
For someone on a business trip for Licorice we very disappointed by the amount or weak availability. A lot of spices Vendors are nice.

VERY large bazzar (we traveled for half a day and still haven't seen half of it). I thought the market was just the dome in the middle, but it's just a tiny fraction of the market. Lots of street food , fruits, vegetables, souviners, spices, knives.. you name it. Pretty much

At first Chorsu Bazaar looked exciting but as I looked closely I realized all the merchants sell nearly the same things. There's very little variety and it gets boring quite quickly. If you don't like crowded, hot places then this is not the right place for you. You won't get

It’s a Nazarene - hot busy and noisy and huge We arrived at 0700 as the stalls were being set up - amazing experience - left at twelve as the days heat started Bought alsorts and spent very little Yes the meat room smells - we just avoided it Great experience - noise -
Spent a few hours here walking around. It is a very local market. The best part was watching the Non bread being made and cooked. Then buying a fresh loaf for 1500 som and eating it hot.
Loads of market stalls, with many kids hassling you to buy from them. A rather off putting smell of raw meat on the lower floor.

Chorsu has variety but if you are a connoisseur, don't expect great quality. Value for money, Yes. Good variety of dry fruits. It's ironic and paradoxical, the place of origin never provides great quality in local markets, perhaps because export fetches the green bucks. Friendly
Chorus is an must experience! Market us where you get to see the kind and welcoming culture of Uzbekistan.
Nice place to see the bazaar and buy nuts and other food items back for your Friends and family back home.

The Bazaar is a central dome shaped structure surrounded by a huge array of stalks outside. My favourite was the bread bazaar with wonderful smells, if you like butchered meat smells the main dime is the place for you. Lots of animal carcasses hanging and kits of huge trays of

Very busy and lots to see! The meat section was fascinating and the fresh fruit and vegetables were cheap and good. The bakery section was great especially eating a piece of bread straight out of the oven!
We got a good products with convenient fairs , lot of different souvenirs and even gifts from owners , clean area. Complements

You must visit this bazaar if you visit Tashkent: so vast and so well organised - a joy to wander around even if you're not planning to buy anything. The displays are fabulous and you will end up buying some fruit, spices or nuts - they just look so good and the prices are

Probably one of the largest Bazaar I have seen. This market is huge and sells everything, you can spend hours wandering around, Do not miss the huge Dome in the middle where the meat sellers are, it is quite a site ! People are very friendly and will often give you some of
I loved visiting this market were you will interact with local that are extremely welcoming. The fresh bread is a must try.

It was raining and quite cold when we visited Chorsu Bazaar in Tashkent. So much to see and so much to buy. Great place to buy dry fruits and the variety is just endless. Some amount of bargaining is required and the shopkeepers are friendly and eager to please. They allow you

I really wish I didn't waste my time. So many stalls selling junk and animals in disgusting conditions. Also a variety of roosters which have obviously been used for fighting. There is a great range of fruit, vegetables and spices which I enjoyed. Everything else was

It’s nothing special selling yet special experience. From farm fresh vegetables to 22 carat gold jewellery to horse meat to Adrus. You can come out without impulse buying. You can’t call your Tashkent trip complete without visiting it. Souvenirs are cheaper then market and more

This enormous covered market is amazing. It is on 2 levels. We were fortunate to be here in Ramadan when many of the stall are closed and many people do not come. At least we could walk around and see things - usually it is so crowded that getting around is tricky let alone
worth visiting. The place where east meets west.There you can find everything, from food to clothing.It is so colorfull .
One of the must sees while visiting Tashkent! So much to see and even to buy and try! Oh my god the bread is amazing!
Nice to walk around - well ordered - clean After you finish go to the back - down the steps and then have a simple adhoc lunch with the locals
Chorsu Bazaar is the best place in Tashkent where you can feel real Uzbekistan. Local food and very nice and friendly people.

Chorsu Bazaar is touted as a must see in Tashkent but it was basically a huge big mess of a market place. As a tourist, there is a small section that sold crafts that would be interesting but most of the place was produce, dried good, and meat that wouldn’t interest the visitor

This must be one of the largest bazaars I've been to - and the variety was staggering - sections specialising from meat to vegetables to bread, sweets and dried fruits. Not to forget the usual market fare of clothing Very easy to get to as it's by the Chorsu metro

Chorsu Bazaar is a huge market in Tashkent. You can buy just about anything in its many halls and rooms. The giant dome is very impressive. The bread making area is particularly interesting. A must for market lovers.

Always like to visit there during my visit to tashkent. Wide variety of fruits vegetables and dry fruits which attracts. Neat and clean area with good hospitable people. Beware there is heavy bargaining and careful while buying things , ask them for best option and quality
Good market for dry fruits you will get dry fruits for unbelievable price and very wide range but you have to bargain a little bit

A bustling and sprawling marketplace for tourist curios, fruits and vegetables, household goods, meats and cheeses, condiments and baked goods. Very good people watching. There are two round buildings and then the usual mix of outdoor stalls. A very good selection of
Good place to go and get an idea of Tashkent daily life. Every kind of food on display and vendors of all kinds floating about.

The chorsu market of Tashkent is worth visiting , very well organized , relatively clean . lot of choice of Vegetables , mouth watering fruits, wide range dry fruits. Almonds , roasted peach seeds, Resins are worth carrying home. Few nice small Souvenirs and gold shops . We
Go to Chorsu bazaar, it's worthwhile. You can get all you want, be it only nice pictures or be it best bargains. You have ro make your own experience.
If you want it, you can probably find it at this market. Fresh produce, meat, dairy products, dried fruit and nuts, cooking oil, bread, clothes, etc...
My teenage son and I had a great afternoon exploring Chorsu. Don’t miss the bread area. Fresh hot local bread right out of the oven. Also, the so same here are the best in Tashkent!

If someone wants to buy something in Tashkent, that's the place. Clothing, household items, vegetables and fruit, breads and meats, arranged according to the subject in various compounds, the vast majority of which are covered by some kind of roof.. We enjoyed the complex of

You can buy almost anything at this market from bottles of saffron to hoarse meat. The various stalls are just fascinating to see what is for sale. The fruit stalls are very colourful as are the spice stalls. A really good market to come to and you can get a hot meal down the
A beautiful structure with different parts for Vegetables, meats and to others. Clean and well laid out. Value for money if you ar buying. Take 45 min to walk around.
Actually you can find everything here, from souvenirs to fresh fruits, cheese and meats, and also cooked food. Market is very clean, and prices are fair

Trying to describe this bazaar is quite easy if you've already been in Asia area. It is a mix of many differents things, from the smallest item you could look for your look going to the typical sweets you desire to get at noon...the food area on my personal opinion is the worth

Must go for spices and dry Fruits Bargaining is the norm here. However with prices being low it does not hurt to pay a few more som. It was quite hot in august even under the dome . I did not find many souvenir shops though.

Market that has everything (starting from groceries and ending by souvenirs). Can’t compare to other markets since haven’t been there. Bought some local dried fruits - very tasty. Can’t say it was cheap. Good place to see how locals do trade. Will definitely come again.

Chorsu Bazar is a must for everyone who enjoys the open markets, who wants to taste the real, authentic, local food and local fruits. The best apricots we ever had were the one we found here! We tried the somsa and we had lunch in the bazar, where the local chefs cook on the
I was there at the wrong time, about 2 in the afternoon, too hot to enjoy it much, it was a good place to get local souvenir.
Useless place. Only for below poverty line people. Oversold , not good quality of dry fruits.Get much better in India

We went there last month to buy dry fruits and bought a whole lot of them from different vendors as there are so many of them. Only after I got back did I realize that the quantities were far less actually. All the one kg packets ranged from 700-800 gm Buyers beware

Very good local market having daily use clothes, eatables, restaurant in open area, dry fruits etc. But it's small There are so many things which I couldn't explore because it was very hot during day time, Worth visiting
Nothing much to see there. Dont think it worth going there that much. Just go there if you have time or you never visit a fresh market.
Large indoor and outdoor market that is busy but safe. Fun to walk thru and see locals buying staples.

Chorsu Bazaar in Tashkent is a popular spot with locals and travellers alike. Cheap pricing for food, clothing, trinkets, all available for bartering too. We picked up some fruits, nuts and spices while we were here.

So enjoyable and fascinating at the same time , to visit this bazaar with its incredible variety of produce, spices, to " die " for , and the list goes on. Local people soooo receptive to my friend and I , having travelled so far for this experience. Definitely where you feel
If you are intending to buy clothes, shoes, food and ...... with cheaper prices then you must visit Chorsu. You will enjoy experiencing the tradition.

If you are an architecture buff than you should see this huge concrete and glass dome that covers the market hall. The market is on two levels and is spectacular. All kinds of stalls, from butchers to spices. If you want to buy nice raisins or sultana’s go upstairs.

This is a great place to buy fresh and dried fruits/nuts etc to take home. The different areas specialise in different products for example there are numerous bakeries, butchers, fruit and vegetable sellers etc The bazaar is very large with a great variety of choice and the

The bazar is quite huge and separated into different "topics". Assumingly if you need supplies you will have tons of opportunities. Of course this also is a huge tourist spot and many shopkeeper know it, so that many of them try to attrackt you. I personally am no friend of this
Its a very interesting place to visit and an easy way to get into the country reality. quite clean and organized place.

A proper bazaar with all sorts of different stuff. One part is currently under reconstruction, thus some entrances are filled with traders side by side. Feeling everything from hand-made exclusives to batteries and everyday items. The central dome is quite interesting,

This market is a great window into daily Uzbek life, people going about their daily business. The market has a huge range of very high quality and beautifully presented goods. The selection of food is amazing. Pick up some fresh bread, literally straight out of the brick oven,

This place could s big and the main hall is over two floors. Here you find fruit, veg, meat and yes also horse meat. On the upper floor dried fruit spices and all types of nuts. Amazing. Next to the main hall the market continues and offers many different products. Great picture
Huge space with hundreds of stalls selling mainly food items such as: dried fruits, nuts, spices, fresh poultry, meat, fruit and vegetables. Good opportunity to take some nice photos.

Chorsu is well worth a visit. It is subdivided in different parts, each with its own offering. The "meat section" in the big dome is amazing (though we doubt that the setting would pass the food safety tests of the EU). Nevertheless, it is a very interesting experience. Be

There was much anticipation of going to Chorsu bazar but quite frankly, it was a let down. The stuff on sale was mostly low quality, cheap knock offs... T-shirts, purses, track pants, sun glasses etc. The local souvenirs were interesting tho. Surprisingly the best part of

Made a quick stop at this market to try to look for some souvenirs. The market is split into different levels selling everything one can imagine. However, it’s too big and too repetitive with many vendors selling the exact same thing. Not a very pushy environment where vendors

The bazaar is worth visiting to experience local shopping. Under the main dome on the ground floor there is every type of meat you could imagine. Upstairs are the dried fruit & nuts. In a separate pavilion is the fruit & vegetables, all incredibly fresh.

After checking with the hotel we made our way by taxi to the Chorsu Bazaar. It is located on two sides of the road. There is one that is going down the steps to stalls, kiosks and shops of plants, fruits, vegetables, and also Uzbek handicrafts.....the second location across the

Chorsu bazaar is a fun place to visit to absorb the smells and sights. The first floor ( ground plus one) houses a bakery where you can see fresh bread being baked and indulge in a hot bread off the oven. Souvenirs are also available. Spend an hour or so here

Typical market on can find, selling fresh produces, meat, dry good. There is large section of the bazaar reserved for bakery, mainly bread they are tasteful, full of aroma. Note that there is no stall for fresh fishes, not sure I missed them. A good experience.

Myself and a friend visited on a weekday during our stay in Tashkent. The driver was able to park inside the gated area of the bazaar. I bought a traditional Uzbek hat, robe & belt for US$20. A friend bought a painting of Tashkent. The bazaar is so big we were not able to visit
This is a ‘must see’ in Tashkent. It is huge and incredibly clean. The fruit and vegetables looked delicious. Sellers display there wares beautifully and were all really friendly .

The place to visit in Tashkent. This place offers variety of choices from wet products to second hand items. Delicious and cheap local food. It’s a place where local people do their shopping and you’ll see local culture at its best.

We went to Chorsu several times. We loved the diverse products, the goods and the cultural experience. We bought food there and a few Uzbek pieces such as clothes to bread stamps to bring home. A must see if visiting and a must do if living in Tashkent.

This is where the locals come to shop. If you are looking for the typical souk type market or souvenirs, you will likely be disappointed. Although there are some “souvenirs” to be found (including some from others areas of Uzbekistan), they are mostly of the “made in China”

An original and authentic experience. Buy local almonds not to leave the place with empty hands. The most of the sellers are uzbek speaking only. Even knowledge of Russian doesn’t help in half of the bargaining cases
It's a good place to visit it's full of traditional Goods fruit snacks Herbst and a lot of interesting things to see

This bazaar has it all, people, traditional clothing, daily foods that the local eats (bread, meat, vegetables, dried fruits, nuts, spices), and many more. Be careful of pick-pocketing, put it in secure place, don't carry big bags. Better to have a local taking you there.

Chorsu is your place for souvenirs if in Tashkent, don't get confused with the dome markets in there as Chorsu is a bit close to the underground station where as most of the domes are meat selling shops which also come under Chorsu! People are real honest and friendly!

Wonderful place to see the food and wares of Uzbekistan. The fruit and vegetables are so vibrant, they look almost fake. Breads section is endless, with each vendor selling their own version of the local favorite. Great place to buy ceramics or embroidered items as well.

Just roam around the place for whatever you want. Pin to piano almost every thing available. Cost effective and many stalls available in market. One of the tourist attractions. Of course you can find this type of market (street market) in almost every country but this is worth

text.wiki:
The Registan was the heart of the ancient city of Samarkand of the Timurid Empire, now in Uzbekistan. The name Rēgistan (ریگستان) means "sandy place" or "desert" in Persian.
The Registan was a public square, where people gathered to hear royal proclamations, heralded by blasts on enormous copper pipes called dzharchis - and a place of public executions. It is framed by three madrasahs (Islamic schools) of distinctive Islamic architecture. The square was regarded as the hub of the Timurid Renaissance.


== Madrasahs ==
The three madrasahs of the Registan are: the Ulugh Beg Madrasah (1417–1420), the Tilya-Kori Madrasah (1646–1660) and the Sher-Dor Madrasah (1619–1636). Madrasah is an Arabic term meaning school.


=== Ulugh Beg Madrasah (1417–1420) ===
The Ulugh Beg Madrasah, built by Ulugh Beg during the Timurid Empire era of Timur—Tamerlane, has an imposing iwan with a lancet-arch pishtaq or portal facing the square. The corners are flanked by high minarets. The mosaic panel over the iwan's entrance arch is decorated by geometrical stylized ornaments. The square courtyard includes a mosque and lecture rooms, and is fringed by the dormitory cells in which students lived. There are deep galleries along the axes. Originally the Ulugh Beg Madrasah was a two-storied building with four domed darskhonas (lecture rooms) at the corners.
The Ulugh Beg Madrasah (Persian: مدرسه الغ بیگ‎) was one of the best clergy universities of the Muslim Orient in the 15th Century CE. Abdul-Rahman Jami, the great Persian poet, scholar, mystic, scientist and philosopher studied at the madrasah. Ulugh Beg himself gave lectures there. During Ulugh Beg's government the madrasah was a centre of learning


=== Sher-Dor Madrasah (1619–1636) ===
In the 17th century the ruler of Samarkand, Yalangtush Bakhodur, ordered the construction of the Sher-Dor (Persian: شیردار‎) and Tillya-Kori (Persian: طلاکاری‎) madrasahs. 
The tiger mosaics with a rising sun on their back, on the face of each madrassa arch are interesting, in that they flout the ban in Islam of the depiction of living beings on religious buildings, especially as they represent the more ancient Persian Mithraic religious motifs. There is a bit of Zoroastrianism influence in the architecture.


=== Tilya-Kori Madrasah (1646–1660) ===
Ten years later the Tilya-Kori (Persian: طلاکاری‎, meaning "Gilded") Madrasah was built. It was not only a residential college for students, but also played the role of grand masjid (mosque). It has a two-storied main facade and a vast courtyard fringed by dormitory cells, with four galleries along the axes. The mosque building (see picture) is situated in the western section of the courtyard. The main hall of the mosque is abundantly gilded.

		
		
		
		
		


== Other buildings ==


=== Mausoleum of Shaybanids ===
To the east of the Tilya-Kori Madrasah, the mausoleum of Shaybanids (16th century) is located (see picture). The real founder of Shaybanid power was Muhammad Shaybani - grandson of Abu'l-Khayr Khan. In 1500, with the backing of the Chaghataite Khanate, then based in Tashkent, Muhammad Shaybani conquered Samarkand and Bukhara from their last Timurid rulers. The founder of the dynasty then turned on his benefactors and in 1503 took Tashkent. He captured Khiva in 1506 and in 1507 he swooped down on Merv (Turkmenistan), eastern Persia, and western Afghanistan. The Shaybanids stopped the advance of the Safavids, who in 1502 had defeated the Akkoyunlu (Azerbaijan). Muhammad Shaybani was a leader of nomadic Uzbeks. During the ensuing years they substantially settled down in oases of Central Asia. The Uzbek invasion of the 15th Century CE was the last component of today's Uzbek nation ethnogeny.


=== Chorsu trading dome ===
The ancient trading dome Chorsu is situated right behind the Sher-Dor.

		


== See also ==
Bibi-Khanym Mosque
Gur-e Amir
Shah-i-Zinda
Timurid dynasty
Tourism in Uzbekistan


== References ==


== External links ==

text.quote: Ornamental public square flanked by 3 historic madrasas built in the 15th & 17th centuries.

The main landmark of Samarkand is stunning not only during daytime but also when lit up. Definitely worth a visit.

Wonderful site to observe from afar and then to walk thru. Be sure to visit the surrounding shops, and market. Amazing architecture, take time to take it all in.

Very high buildings, when you enter you jist feel yourself in a very luxury place. You can take thousands of photos and still want to visit this place again. Also, there is an ice cream shop which serves the most delicious ice cream in the world.

Everything they say about it is true - the scale, the majesty, the beauty. A truly amazing sight in afternoon sunlight, and breathtaking at night. The highlight of any trip to Uzbekistan.
This was possibly the highlight of the entire trip. While reconstructed, the breathtaking beauty is not to be missed. Simply amazing
Spectacular site to see the opulence that once was Samarkand. At night we returned to enjoy the light and sound show with other tourists and visitors. Very friendly and welcoming environment.
The azure and Belize make the mosaic brilliant.. its size keeps one in awe through out the tour... it’s just beautiful.

text.wiki:
Greater Chimgan (3,309 m) of the Chatkal Mountain range (the Western Tian Shan) is located in the territory of the Ugam-Chatkal National Park, and it is in the Bostanlyk administrative district (Tashkent Province), Uzbekistan.

The Chimgan village was settled 400–500 years ago in the mountain massive of dominant the Greater Chimgan peak (3,309 m), at an altitude of 1,620 m.
Some experts see Chinese words in the name "Chimgan" but others translate it as "sod" or "pasture abundant in water, green valley".
For generations of those, who live in Tashkent province, the Greater Chimgan is the place of romantic gravitation.
Greater Chimgan (3,309m) has been known to mountaineers since the beginning of the 20th century.
For those who want to experience of rock climbing, hiking and mountaineering Chimgan Highlands caters many opportunities. Chimgan Highlands have been a host for many other outdoor activities such as hang gliding, skiing, snowboarding and horseback riding.For many years the Greater Chimgan was the first challenge for thousands beginners of Soviet mountaineering.
A great number of routes of several levels of complexity (from 1B to 4B inclusively) allows a wide spectrum of mountaineering. Beginners at climbing usually take on the uncomplicated western ridge of the Greater Chimgan Mountain (1B), while there are plenty of more complicated routes for experienced climbers.


== Climate and seasons ==
Climatic conditions in Chimgan are determined by the mountainous part of the Ugam-Chatkal National Nature Park. The climate is continental; there are seasonal and daily fluctuations. During the day it is warm, the evenings are cool. Spring comes in April in the mid-mountains; in the high mountains there is snow and cold until midsummer. The highest temperature is in June–July and early-August. Mean daily temperature of the warmest month (July) fluctuates from 20 to 35 degrees Celsius. Average annual precipitation is 650 mm. Heavy snowfall is in winter, which allows skiing and snowboarding. Snow cover lasts for 4–5 months. The frost period lasts about 130 days.


== Accessibility ==
Chimgan is located 60 km from Gazalkent regional centre and 40 km from Hojikent railway station. The closest airport having international and local importance is in Tashkent, 100 km away. A new expressway from Tashkent to Hojikent is paved with high-quality pavement; in some places there is artificial illumination. Chimgan is further reachable from Gazalkent by public bus (50 min). There are bus routes Chimgan-Gazalkent (time of departure is 6:30 and 13:30) and Gazalkent-Chimgan (10:30 and 14:30). Private cars including taxis can also be used to get there. The road is accessible any time of the year, but in spring there can be limitations because of landslides and mudflows. In winter avalanches make the route dangerous. Alternative means of transportation are helicopters (but their use is limited).

text.wiki:
Lake Charvak (Uzbek: Chorvoq; from چهارباغ Char bagh, "four gardens" in Persian) is a water reservoir in Bostanliq District in the northern part of Tashkent Region, Uzbekistan, separating Ugam (north), Pskem (east), and Chatkal (south) ranges. The reservoir was created by erecting a 168 m (551 ft) high stone dam (Charvak Hydropower Station) on the Chirchiq River, a short distance downstream from the confluence of Pskem, Ko'ksu and Chatkal rivers in the western Tian Shan mountains, which provide the main volume of water. Currently the confluence cannot be seen and all three rivers discharge directly into Charvak. The reservoir capacity is 2 km3 (0.48 cu mi).Lake Charvak is the uppermost of the several reservoirs made on the Chirchiq River. Downstream, there are Khodzhikent Reservoir and Gazalkent Reservoir, which have a much smaller area.The dam construction was started in 1964 and completed in 1970. About 150 archaeological sites were submerged under water when the reservoir was filled up. These sites were investigated by the Institute of History and Archaeology of Uzbekistan before the dam was constructed.Lake Charvak is a popular resort in Tashkent region and thousands of holiday makers from all over Uzbekistan and neighbouring countries visit the reservoir. Villages on the banks of Charvak such as Yusufhona, Burchmulla, Nanay, Chorvoq, Sidjak, Bogustan, and their surroundings offer wide range of hotels, dachas, houses and tapchans to accommodate tourists. Yusufhona is also a popular place among paragliders and provides facilities for this sport.


== References ==


== External links ==

text.wiki:
Islam Karimov Tashkent International Airport (Uzbek: Islom Karimov Toshkent Xalqaro Aeroporti – (IATA: TAS, ICAO: UTTT)) is the main international airport of Uzbekistan and the 3rd busiest airport in Central Asia (after Almaty International Airport and Nursultan Nazarbayev International Airport in Kazakhstan). It is located 12 km (7.5 mi) from the center of Tashkent.


== Overview ==
This ICAO Category II airport is the primary hub of Uzbekistan Airways, and is the largest international airport in Uzbekistan, and the busiest in Central Asia. The airport comprises two terminals: Terminal 2 receives international flights, Terminal 3 is for domestic traffic.Terminal 2 was rebuilt in 2001, and renovations were completed in 2018. It has a capacity of 1000 passengers/hour and serves more than two million passengers per year. Other facilities include waiting lounges, CIP and VIP halls, restaurants and bars, currency exchange offices, duty-free shops, airlines ticket counters and sales offices, and a 24-hour pharmacy. The terminal operates at near maximum capacities; arriving passengers frequently spend an average of two hours completing customs and immigration formalities.
Terminal 3 opened in 2011 with a capacity of 400 passengers per hour. The two terminals are separated by the runway, requiring passengers transiting from international to domestic flights and vice versa to exit the airport in order to transfer between them.
The government of Uzbekistan is planning to relocate Tashkent Airport to a new site by 2030.

text.wiki:
Sayid Muhammad Khudayar Khan, usually abbreviated to Khudayar Khan, was a Khan of Kokand who reigned between 1845 and 1875 with interruptions. He was the son of Shir Ali Khan. During the reign of Khudayar Khan, the Khanate was suffering from a civil war and from interventions of the Emir of Bukhara. Subsequently, the Russian invasion into Central Asia first forced the Khanate to become a vassal of the Russian Empire, and in 1876 the Khanate was abolished as a result of the suppression of an uprising. In 1875, Khudayar Khan, who took a pro-Russian position, during the uprising had to flee to Orenburg in Russia. He died in exile.


== Prelude to rule ==
In 1845, Shir Ali Khan was killed during the uprising. His son Murad Beg Khan was declared the khan briefly, however, he was soon overthrown and eventually executed by the supporters of Shir Ali Khan, since he was considered to be a puppet of the Emir of Bukhara. The main political figure in the Khanate was Mingbashi Musulmonqul, a military commander, who declared Khudayar Khan, his son-in-law, the khan of Kokand. Khudayar was in Namangan during the uprising and thus survived. In the 1840s, Khudayar Khan was essentially locked in the palace in Kokand, whereas the Kipchak nomad elite under Musulmonqul had all the power in the Khanate. In 1853, there was an uprising against the Kipchaks, and a large number of them were killed, including Musulmonqul. Khudayar Khan continued to rule on his own and took an anti-Kipchak and pro-Uzbek position. He put the northern parts of the Khanate under special government, and appointed Mirza Akhmad to be the governor. In 1858, the northern provinces rebelled. Khudayar Khan sent his brother Malla Bek to Tashkent to suppress the rebellion. Instead, Malla Bek joined the rebels, conquered Kokand, and proclaimed himself a khan. He was supported by Alimqul, a Kipchak and a powerful warlord. Khudayar had to flee.


== Rise to power ==

In 1862, Muhammad Malla Beg Khan was assassinated, and his nephew, Shah Murad Khan, became the khan. The ruler of Tashkent, Kanaat, allied with Khudayar, and Shah Murad besieged Tashkent. At the same time, Muzaffar, the Emir of Bukhara, advanced to Kokand. As the result, the Kokand army disappeared, the siege of Tashkent was lifted, and Khudayar moved to Kokand and declared himself a khan. In the meanwhile, in Osh, Alimqul got rid of possible throne claimants, promising all of them the throne, prompting them to go to Osh and executing them. In July 1863, he proclaimed Muhammad Sultan Khan, a son of Muhammad Malla Beg Khan, the Khan of Kokand. Alimqul himself was a regent, since Sultan was about thirteen years old. He launched an attack on the Khudayar's forces, and at the same time Muzaffar had to return to Bukhara to suppress a rebellion which started in Shahrisabz. Alimqul managed to agree with the Emir, launched simultaneous attacks on Kokand and Tashkent, and finally took them under control.


== Rule of Kokand and legacy ==
In the 1850s, the Russian Empire advanced to the Central Asia with the final goal of controlling the whole area. In 1865, Russian troops took Tashkent, and Alimqul, who opposed them, was killed in action. In Kokand, Kipchaks declared Hudaykul Bey the khan, however, after a fortnight he flew to Kashgar. Subsequently, Khudayar Khan entered Kokand without any resistance. In 1866, Russians proceeded to the south, occupying Khujand, and thus physically separating the Kokand Khanate and the Bukhara Emirate. In 1868, Khudayar formally accepted the sovereignty of the Russian Empire over the Khanate.The reign of Khudayar Khan in the 1860s was notable for extremely high taxes and dysfunctional legal system, which was even worse than what his predecessors installed. In 1870, a plot was discovered, in which opponents of Khudayar Khan tried to replace him with Seyid Khan, a son of Mallya Khan, living in exile in Bukhara. When the plot was discovered, and Seyid Khan killed, the Emir of Bukhara, to avoid accusations in support of the plot, sent Khudayar Khan the names of conspirators and their supporters. This led to a large amount of executions. In 1875, an uprising has forced Khudayar Khan to flee from the khanate.The palace built by Khudayar Khan is one of the landmarks of Kokand.

A not very imposing structure at the standard of samarkand and uzbekistan, the mousleum of emir temur is just off the main boulovard and the statue of the amir himself in round about. fee is there as usual . at night the whole area and especially the attraction is well lit.
The inside a very gaudy, but interesting with the illumination and the local mullahs chanting the Quran.
this is an amazing mausoleum, one of the Uzbekistan/Samarkand highlights. At night it is well-lit, quiet and worth a visit for a cheaper entrnce fee.

Yet another amazing place to visit in Samarkand. the beautiful blue dome on the outside is reflected inside within the mausoleum. The tombs of many famous uzbek figures are buried here. The central room is beautifully done with the tombs in the middle.

This great 14th century conqueror of much of Central Asia rests here with some of his family. This is one of the finest mausoleums in the city. While visiting Samarkand, be sure to visit the bazaar - a photographer's paradise.
The dome on this Mausoleum is brilliant. It draws your eyes upwards. Inside it reminds you that we are all mortal even if you are a great ruler like Timur.

Tamerlane (or Amir Timur) is buried in a simple and yet grandiose mausoleum. The green slab of hard stone marking the tomb lays among other tombs severely aligned. The vast dome over the tombs is covered in paintings and mosaics inside, and with green and blue mosaics outside.

This mausoleum has significant historical significance, and there are some signs in English to help English speaking tourists. There is also a map at the entrance to help to understand the conquests of Temur - which adds to the overall understanding of this place.
In my opinion, the most beautiful cupola in the Islamic world....certainly the best one in Samarkand, and there is lots of competition

Amir Teymour tomb was destroyed once & rebuilt by his grandson later, there are some parts still under reconstruction. inside the building there are 9 tombs including Amir Teymour & his son/grandsons & teacher etc. I think It's the first place to visit in Samarqand considering

one man's hero is another man's criminal ... Amir Teymor dominated and terrorized Central asia, far east and middle east during his life, he build many monuments and burned down many monuments as well...he is uzbekistans national Hero so, check this place out, and respect it.

Visited as one of the historical place in Samarkand. Interesting place and interesting legend (relation between scientists opened the grave and the start of the Second World War). Also it is curious to see how Tamerlan admired his Teacher - Teacher's tomb is the first and

Difficult to explain why, but it just was. I loved the tranquility, the setting, the decorations, everything. And most of all the little patches or original wall covering they left here and there to see what it looked like before renovations.
There is a sad story attached to this mausoleum which the Emir had built for his grandson. He wanted to be buried in his home town but was buried here instead.
This is one of the places where my mouth fell open in full awe. I had no idea any building could be so lavishly decorated, so rich, so fine, so tasteful and so artistically.
This is one of the many beautiful constructions in this country. The only down side of the visit was being pestered by a local gypsy woman asking for money

sights.name: UNODC Regional Office for Central Asia - Uzbekistan

trip: Lusine organized our 19 day tour in Central Asia and it was excellent. She and the other staff working with Arara were helpful, fast to respond to concerns and all around very professional. The tour itself does well to show you the wonders of all 5 Central Asian countries. My

I did the 5 country tour through all 5 ‘Stan’ countries and I can comfortably recommend this (admittedly quite long) tour to anyone. While 23 days certainly is a long time on the road, its necessary in order to see the wonders of Central Asia. Arara does just that, the tour is

First, I’d like to say thank you to the team at Arara, they wrote me after I got home from my tour and I’m happy to do so, given their high quality service and excellent tour program. Arara makes sure you see the best of Central Asia, eat the best food and have genuine

We just returned from Central Asia after two weeks and I have to say we had the trip of a lifetime. We ended up choosing the Five Wonders of Central Asia tour and enjoyed every minute of it. I’d always dreamed of seeing the wonders of the old silk road and my wife and I were

I had a fantastic experience in Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan and Tajikistan on the 15 day tour. Everything was well organized and the tour had a good mix of history, nature and culture. I especially enjoyed the food and the visits to the various bazaars and markets. I was especially

text.wiki:
The following is a list of the tallest buildings in the world by country listing only the tallest building in each country. The list is including only completed (or at least topped-out) buildings. A total of 20 countries featured in the list have supertall skyscrapers (300 m and more). Many countries have constructed new tallest buildings in the 2010s, with the oldest tallest building in a country being Caracol in Belize, which has stood as the country's tallest building since 1200 BC.


== Completed ==
The list includes the tallest (completed or topped out) buildings in each country in the world. All measurements are as defined and recognised by the Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat (CTBUH). Heights are measured to architectural top, with antennae being excluded.


== Under construction ==
The list includes the tallest (under construction) buildings that will become its nation's tallest building upon completion.


== References ==

text.quote: Cemetery site with many ornately decorated, colorful tombs & ancient mosaic-tiled mausoleums.
trip: This is another must visit attraction in Samarkand. The architecture here with the many colourful tiles is beautiful.

Shah i Zinda, comes from Persian which means "The Living King". Consists of several buildings in the form of mausoleums and other buildings including the mosque. Built from the 9th to the 14th centuries. The name Shah-i-Zinda is connected to Kusam Ibn Abbas, a cousin of the
I highly recommend to visit this monument! I was so touched with the color of blue. I took photos all the time. It’s better to visit in the morning for the reason of backlight.

On the northern part of Samarkand, in the settlement of Afrasiab, there is one of the most mysterious and unique archtiectural monuments of Samarkand. Mainly the Shah-i-Zinda. It consists of two rows of refine sparkling blue colored tombs. Harmoniously combined in a lively and

I’ve heard people suggest that Shah-i-Zinda is better than Registan, and truthfully I don’t know where I fall on that one - but I don’t think it’s important. Both are absolutely incredible places, the likes of which I have never seen before and which alone justify a trip to
This place is the most photogenic place in all of Samarkand. The bright coloured mausoleums were super beautiful.

This tiered complex of mausoleums, tombs and buildings is a spectacular example of architecture from the 11th - 19th centuries. The stunning mosaics of the buildings is just the start - decorations are carved mosaic, majolica tiles and irrigation bricks.

It is the collective effect which is impressive. The individual mausoleams are each wonderful examples of architectural and ceramic art, but it is the linear succession of them which is truly stunning. And so far as I could see, each one is different from its fellows.
This too is one of the highlights of Samarkand. Very busy with many worshipers coming and going. Well worth stopin for. Count the steps.

The complex has various beautifully decorated mosaic-tiled mausoleums, and it is widely visited by both locals and visitors. The complex is a calm and sacred place which makes people feel rather peaceful while admiring ancient Islamic art.
It’s also known as Necropollis .... an avenue of mausoleums ...series of grand palatial tombs .. unique architectural monuments

We came on a Tuesday around 3 pm and it was pretty crowded. It is like an avenue with beautiful mausoleums right and left. The mausoleums here were built in the 11th through 19th centuries. The blue tile work is beautiful. We spent around 1 hour here.
Take time to explore this place, go with a local guide (you'll get more from it) and be ready for an amazing sunset on top!
This is a large site that includes madrasas , praying sites and sacred burriels site . Unfortunately , the explanations are minimal and you must use a guide for reasonable understanding
There are lots extraordinary sights in and around Samarkand - and this is one of them. Not to be missed.

Even though it is a collection of mausoleums, it is a beautiful complex. Well restored so one can enjoy the beauty of each mausoleum, it is an easy 3 hour visit. The narrow bylanes add to the aura of an ancient period.
I'm sure it's great inside but totally inaccessible to wheelchair users, unfortunately. A shame but other nearby sites are.

It's a closely-spaced collection of mausoleums for the early rulers (and their family members) of the Timurid dynasty. Some mausoleums are richly decorated, others less so. Worth a close look at the terracotta and tilework. I would have liked more information about the evolution
This is probably the single most important Silk Road Samarkand site to explore. It puts on full display the wealth and power of the Timur dynasty. A Must See in Samarkand.

Shah-i Zinda, which literally means the king who is alive, is complex of tombs which belong to the dignitaries of Samarkand. These range from religious scholars to the politicians of the ancient times. Some of the interior space where the tombs are located are really beautiful

We have seen some extraordinary tilework before - notably in our trip to Bursa in Turkey and Esfahan in Iran - but I really cannot think of anywhere which surpasses Shah-i-Zinda in terms of impact. The mass of blue, green and turquoise tiles is breath-taking, as is the array of
It just gets better and better. We didnt know anything about this site and it is mind blowing. A line of mausoleums each one spectacularly decorated and each one different. A real experience

So many tombs to explore; all with different styles of architecture and stories to tell. The tile works on most of them were amazing and make the most beautiful photographs. Do give yourself plenty of time to walk round the site as there is so much to see and take in. A guide

A short walk from the Siyob Market, is this amazing grouping of mausoleums of civil servants and other VIPS dating back to t he 14-15th century is simply gorgeous. Be prepared to climb a long staircase to get to it, but it is well worth it. It's not easy to get panoramic photos
Really beautiful place with lots of history within itself. Visited during the day and it’s wasn’t that crowded.

This stunning site is an avenue of mausoleums containing some of the richest tilework in the Muslim world. It started with a single religious monument over 1000 yrs. ago. The complex consists of eleven mausoleums which were continuously added form the 11th century to the 15th

The rich blue and green tile work on this avenue of Mausoleums that goes back seven centuries is quite spectacular and as interesting as it can get. Inside the work varies in terms of being elaborate to just plain. There are also at least two mosques and hence it is a religious

A wonderful experience walking around the complex after sunset. All looked so mysterious... A good reminder of being in present moment and cherish the life.
