wonderful line of tombs, which despite its sacred value, remains very lively - numerous locals congregate here and it is fascinating also for the people - highly recommended to the itinerary in Samarcand.
The blue tilework was incredie. Everytime I thought I had got to the end of the alley, it just kept on going. This was my favourite place in sarkhand.
Shah-I-zindeh is a complex of mausoleums, where important historical figures are buried. Each building is dedicated and interesting in history and architecture.
Wow this place is impressive. You can get an electric buggy from rejistan for 10p This was my favourite place in Samarkand

Set inside a regular cemetery lies this amazing complex of mausoleums; these are for special people while the cemetery is for ordinary people without special religious or secular rank. Much history is associated with this place, so it's best to have a guide to gain background
The best place in Samarkand next to registan! Enjoy the ensemble of graves and take some nice pictures with the sun and the turquoise colors!

Shah-I-Zinda was the highlight of my Samarkand visit. The complex is made up of at least a dozen mausoleums concentrated in one area. Each dome housing a mausoleum is unique in design and each impressive with beautiful tile work.

Shah-i-Zinda is a magnificent site. It is an avenue of Mauseleums. The site has some of the best islamic tilework antwhere in the world. The name means "Tomb of the Living King". The tombs span the 7th to 15th centuries. Just wander around and enter the various buildings to see

Sahi E Zinda is undoubtedly the Top attraction of Samarkand. A complex of mausoleum dating from 7 th century till 15 th century. Grand architecture and spending and explicit Tile work. There are tombs of Various people , family members of Taimur , sisters ,cousins ,nephews ,
You should take time of at least two hours for this stunny visit. Watch the many steps. You can distiguish the different periods the mausolees were built.

This is probably the best place I’ve been in Samarkand. Beautiful architecture and the mosaics of where the great kings are buried are just breathtaking. The prayer room inside is also very pretty with locals coming to pray when visiting. It is a holy place so beware of being
This area is small, but if you like to take photos, you'll take plenty. I like that each mausoleum has a small sign out front telling who is buried there are any specific architectural details.
This was the highlight of our stay in Samarkand. Very impressive sight with beautiful monuments. It is just a 10 minutes walk away from the Bazaar. Definitely worth visiting.

One of the highlights of our trip to Uzbekistan! Absolutely stunning set of mausoleums and buildings with the most amazing tile work - all dating from 1200's? I think - and maybe more recent. If you ever go to Samarkand do NOT miss this sight.
Not as well known as Registan, but certainly worth a visit. The visiting conditions have changed: you can walk around, take pictures and enjoy the magnificent monuments.
A place that you must visit to see the actual works and architecture of Uzbek. Some awesome color, which is very well maintained and definitely a place for photographers.
great history relived ...walk through the olden times with a good guide and you realise the importance of these monuments

The Shah-i Zinda complex comprises a narrow street of late 14th- and early 15th-century tombs along a steep hill. The shrine of a Muslim saint, the raison d'etre for the whole street, is near the end, at the top; don't neglect to go all the way in, past a 15th-century carved

One of the most interesting necropole I have ever seen, perfectly restored, beautiful facades and interiors of the tombs; well described before the entrances. No visit in Samarkand could be complete without it. Relatively not expensive entrance fee (if compared with Ulug Beg

amazing place. A relatively large number of mausoleums of the wealthy of the late Moslem period, beautiful exterior designs and modest interior designs for male graves and a magnificent design for the female graves. An amazing site for photography of countless beautifull

It is another amazing monument in the city. While you walk inside this amazing place you feel like you have a short trip to ancient times. At the entrance there are stairs and before stepping in make a wish and then start counting the stairs, do the same when you are going out.
This place was a photo mecca and the structures were just fabulous to see and just wander around. There are so many buildings and each has its beauty
It among the top things to do in Samarkand. Many mausoleums, some more interesting then others. Apparently, Mohamed Ali has a famous photo of him taken there. Overall, not to be missed..
This collection of mausoleums that date to the 14th and 15th Centuries is not to be missed. Wonderous facades and interiors covered with ceramic mosaics. It is a photographers dream.

A fabulous collection of mausoleums with glorious tiles. Do walk to the end to see it all, you won't be disappointed by the Mausoleum of Kusam ibn Abbas, a cousin of The Prophet Muhammad, who is believed to have died in Samarkand

This place is in absolute must if you are in Samarkand. I was blown away by the beauty of the architecture in all the buildings. It is busy but you must visit here you wont regret it. As an FYI There is a photography fee that is separate to the entrance ticket

Our group was brought here after visiting Daniel's Tomb. Arriving at 11 AM on a Sunday morning, our bus struggled to find a place for our discharge. We then joined the crowds of locals and tourists up the long series of steps, then cautiously proceed along the narrow pathway

When we arrived there, we were told going there 3 times and then you are an Hajjaji, so I am one third Hajjaji now ;) Not only the architecture was stunning, but there were also Imams at the entrance who recited a sura from quor'an for me - Islamic culture pure, absolutely
Entry price 22.000 som. Great place for photography. Take a guide book for explaining all the stories of the sites.

This was my favourite sight in Samarkand, along with the Registan. The old, narrow pathway weaving inbetween the huge majestically-tiled mausoleums is very atmospheric. Best of you can time it to miss the large tour groups - beginning, end or middle of day.
This is a succession of mausoleums in a confined space. Beautiful tile work throughout and exquisite artistry.

While this site offers, according to the guide books, some unequaled architecture, it is a bit cramped and claustrophobic compared to other grand venues in Samarkand. It is also on a steep hill with many steps. That said, it's pretty fabulous.
For us it was impressing to see all these magnificent tombs in the same place. The history of each one of them is very beautiful and you should take a local guide . A guide is a must here.

It is a complex of Mausoleums from the time of Timur The Great. Each Mausoleum is unique in its style & beauty. You do need to climb several stair as it is on top of a hill, no wheel chair accessible. It is recommended to spend atleast 3-4 hours to see all the mausoleums.

The Registan may be Samarkand's poster child, but for me the real star of the show is the line of the blue and turquoise tiled tombs known as the Sha-i-Zinda. The tombs at the complex are loosely grouped: the earliest ones are thjose at the north of the site, that date from the

I believe it is one of the most highly decorated Mausoleum I have visited. Easy to find and sitting on the hill side. You should walk there once you finish Registon, the bazaar and the old Jewish quarter.
I liked so much! It is hard to express how I liked that, I am not a big traveler but I have seen many interesting places in that world. This one is one of my favourite.
This is an amazing place to visit. Too bad we went during afternoon time which is bad lighting for photography. Morning time will be much better!

this place in the last visit of a very busy day in Samarkand and with the sun going down it was really an amazing experience. About 15 Mausoleums and Two mosques in a complex of incredible beauty. Enlightenment peace serenity and beauty
Magnificent street of mausoleums, well preserved. This site should not be missed. For photographers, a visit in the morning and afternoon can be rewarding

Another gem and a 10 minute walk from Bibi Khanym mosque. If you go via the cemetery side, you might not have to pay an entry fee. The cemetery itself is also interesting. Go early for the morning light.

Be prepared for stunning architecture and grueling steps, as you ascend 800+ years of history. This is a pilgrimage site for those of Muslim faith, a cousin of the Prophet Muhammad is believed to be buried here. The tile work absolutely glows.

This place is simply wow! I don’t have a passion for cemeteries or mauzoleis but this place is stunning with blue wall ornaments, eneteriers, wooden doors etc. highly recommended to be visited when in Samarkand!!
Absolutely breathtaking lovely and historic collection of buildings, with many steps to achieve the upper area. One of the finest sites in Uzbekistan

The Brandt book on Uzbekistan says they've always loved to come in from the side of the modern cemetery and "take a trip back through history." Of course there's a little side benefit of "taking a trip back through history"... they never come right out and say it, but one gets
Another must see place. The amount of details, the proportions, it is al gorgeous. Really worthwhile.
We had no idea what to expect and this ended up being our favorite place to explore in Samarkand! It's a real necropolis and it's fascinating and stunning!
A row of beautifully decorated mausoleums - one of the highlights of Samarkand. A photographer's dream.
Spectacular spot with mausoleums from different ages. Considered a holy place, so beware of your behavior. Definitely worth a visit!

Shah-I Zinda is relatively compact (compared to the more famous Registan complex for example) and yet overwhelming In its beauty. From the street a pathway leads through a lower gate and nice porch for resting (lovely painted ceiling here) and then up steep stairs (no

Visiting this place is definitely an experience. You will be immersed within a colorful necropolis, full of Uzbek people. The picture is unique, at least in the whole Samarkand. The decorations of the mausoleums are wonderful. It has not to be missed once in Samarkand.

This whole area is complex of some beautiful tombs which were built during 9th century to 14 century with beautiful blue tile which breathtaking since I come from india easily understand the importance of this very place because their descendants constructed tombs later in 16

It's almost too much to take in, all the beautiful mausoleums with amazing tilework and decoration. I almost preferred the intimate beauty to the grandeur of the Registan. On a side note, there are a lot of stairs so someone with mobility issues may struggle here.
The place is a little less busy latter in the afternoon and cooler. Still wonderful buildings with huge wooden carved doors . The cemetery itself is worth seeing

Here are the family members of the ruler Timur buried and this site is massive. It is not possible to take a picture of the whole area as it is too big but there are many amazing shots to be taken. You can visit most mausoleums and some are just stunning. Don’t miss this place.

One of the loveliest cemeteries I have even been to, the Shah-I-Zinda is amazing to see all the small mausoleums and the people, lots of locals visiting family crypts and leaving gifts, saying prayers and of course tourists admiring the craftsmanship of all of them as most
Another must see. Pictures don't give the full color and size. If you love blue, this is the place to see .
A must in Samarkand. Tranquility, sеrenity and peace. The best time is to come at the end of the day when it is not so crowdy.

I loved Shah-I-Zinda. The mausoleums are spectacular, with beautiful tiles. I recommend going early as it can get quite crowded. Ladies should cover their heads here. There is a good WC outside and on the right of the entrance. You need at least an hour for a good visit.
One of the most interesting places in Samarkand. Select to visit it early in the morning as later is very crowdy
Coming from Bukhara it was amazing to see the fantastically decorated buildings of Samarkand - very beautiful and impressive. Recommended!
this place is perhaps not so impressive as registan but definitely a must see as well . these are the places you won’t forget after your visit to samarqand

Samarkand is blessed with many 'not to be missed' attractions and this is certainly one of them! There are some twenty buildings here, dating mainly from the 9th-14th centuries and some from the 19th century. The name of the place is linked to the legend that Kusam ibn Abbas
Samarkand has most beautiful old buildings I have ever seen in my life. It has Registan, Bibi-Khanim, Shakh-i-Zinda...etc. With simple word I would highly recommend to go and visit there

There are about 20 mausoleums all beautiful and differently decorated. Climb the steps to the complex then gradually wander round the many buildings going into some of them to see the equally beautiful and different interiors. So much to see in one place makes it really worth a
The royal tombs gives a serene ambient of tranquility and beauty. It is postcard like wherever you turn and good pictures are produced with just clicks of camera. A must visit site in Samarkand.
All the sites in Samarkand are awesome. This visit was part of my religious studies tour and it far exceeded my expectations

Walking the narrow streets of the necropolis, the curving streets and beautiful tall tiles facades are unique. Its hard to find a place that is totally 'different' I would argue this is one such place. It was a moving, serene and beautiful place.

The Shah-i-Zinda Ensemble includes mausoleums and other ritual buildings of 9-14th and 19th centuries. The name Shah-i-Zinda (meaning "The living king") is connected with the legend that Kusam ibn Abbas, the cousin of the prophet Muhammad was buried there.

Khiva, Bukhara and then fabulous Samarkand evoking ancient tales of the silk road and the exotic. Samarkand does not disappoint. The Bibi-Khanum Mosque, the Regestan with its three Madrassahs, the mausoleums at the Shah-i-Zinda, the ancient site at the Afrasiyab with its ancient
This is a great place to get a feel for Samarkand architecture over the last few centuries. It is also adjacent to an interesting cemetery that is worth strolling through.
Shah-i- Zinda is a collection of ancient mausoleums. Acqua domes top tombs completely encrusted in faience tiles.

I've seen many mosaic decorated architectures but have never seen something quite like this in terms of pattern, artistic style, and size. Not only the way they built burial places for the royal families is unique, but the mosaic art there is also what sets it apart. Spend at

I looked at my wife and we both said, "wow." From the lower grouping, to the middle grouping, to the upper grouping, and then into the city cemetery, there was eye candy everywhere. Stunning tile work, architecture, a packed encylopedia of Islamic culture. I think the most
As other sights in Samarkand, this is a highlight of a trip through Usbekistan. You shouldn't miss she Schahi-Sinda (also the cementary). We were deeply impressed.
I can’t really recognize this place as it were just one of many I saw on a day tour. See it on a half day taxi tour of Afrosiab. Then forget about it.
You can spend hours walking through its beautiful buildings in blue, it's a magical place. Really worth to visit and to spend a while in.
A must go in Samarkand!!! The blue tombs are perfect matches to the blue sky!! I stayed there until sunset, where the sun was setting down Bibi Xonum madrasah. It was amazing

Beautiful collection of buildings, mostly mausoleums with the usual blue ceramic tiles. After a while it becomes difficult to distinguish one from another, simply because they all have such ornate facades.
Probably my favourite site in Samarkand. The tombs are wonderfully decorated in blue tiles. A must see

Here it's one of the most important places for the small Haj , because of the Kussam Ebn Abbas's grave , who was a cousin of Muhammad . In the site , you can see other graves that are belongings to Timur Lang and Ulugbak family . The attractions has a beautiful city view , and
The monument Shah-i-Zinda was one of the highlights of my trip to Samarkand. It's a must visit place while in Uzbekistan
This street of mausoleums is well worth a visit . The architecture , design and decoration is spectacular . Again worth hiring a local guide to understand the background and history .

This is basically a very old cemetery. Do look at the various tombs, which are all architectural gems. You will find that the most of the visitors are locals who are there in great reverence. A group of ladies insisted on having their picture taken with us!

This Necropolis built on a Hill not far fromthe Registan in Samarkand is a magnificent collection of tombs and Mausoleums flanking a narrow passageway which can be reached by climbing a flight of many stairs. At the entrance one is met with the sights of young and old climbing

Amazing series of mausoleums, each one almost more beautiful than the last. Unfortunately our tour took us here in the middle of a Sunday when it was packed. If you have the option, go first or last thing.

Interesting when you take into account all the 'normal' gravestones behind the complex. It gives the impression that the rich and famous wanted a lasting memorial to themselves, and the got it, which the tourists and more so the local Uzbek people are paying for to maintain with
Entry ticket is required. You need to wear modestly, no short allowed, and cover your head. It is worth seeing

Uzbekistan is one of those hidden gems. This mausoleum is one example, a series of well preserved, gigantic and colorfull tombs. The walk is simply amazing sorrounded by that uzbek turquiose color all over

With every step you take you'll encounter another remarkable turquoise and blue tiled tomb, all worth exploring. Don't forget to look up to see some stunning ceilings. Then check out the most recent burials whose tombstones are differently impressive. Do go.

We went only because we had some spare time. We were lucky. This is not to be missed. There are a series of mausoleums at this place, each one truly exquisite. Take your time seeing each work and appreciate the intricate different tile work.

It was really busy when I went which was a bit frustrating as it ruins the atmosphere a little but as it is an active place of worship i suppose this is normal. Take water and sunscreen. A guide might be useful for this site if you haven't had a chance to read up on it
The most beautiful place of Samarkand. Amazing for photo and seeing daily life of Uzbek. You can get there through an interesting cemetery.

Though more low key than the Registan, this avenue of mausoleums shows off the best tile work of any Islamic architecture anywhere else in the world. Entrance fee is modest for a westerner - take your time walking around. For those wanting to explore further, there is a path up

Some tombs are quite beautiful and others plain. The tombs are set on either side a lane, and form three quite distinct eras of erection. The profusion of tile-work would now be passé for those who have may have seen Bibi Xonim or Registon before the Shah-I-Zinda visit. But all
Must-see when visiting Samarkand. Beautiful collection of tombs. Definitely worth the entrance fee (10k for foreigners)

Most of Samarkand is modern and has little sense of history. The main attractions are all walkable, being less than 3 ks between the Amir Temur tomb and this amazing necropolis, and most is tree lined walkways. All the sites in this area are historical and beautiful, and there

The architecture of Samarkand of Temurid time (14th - 15th centuries) is called an International Architecture and the necropolis Shakhi Zinda is the place which proves it. It's a must-see in Samarkand with over 20 mausoleums standing one to another,

At the entrance they where the only place in Uzbekistan to bother the few tourists with stupid trousers and skirts to cover you up even more...we already where dressed decently. Entrance fee is high and you pay extra for your camera...a trend that really has to stop in
You can't imagine from outside how many rich blue-domes pantheons are inside, very nice. Also interesting that many local people go there, it's a real approach to Uzbeks, very friendly.
absolutely impressive… creative structures… As if I was walking in history… all that historic buildings should be protected carefully...

This row of restored mausoleums is absolutely stunning, and essential to see, although crowded with visitors and pilgrims. Samarkand has chosen to restore the site's past glories, rather than to leave it in its former partly-ruined condition, a much-debated choice in the world

What an amazing place. Awfully hot day but the walk through and around this historic site is not to be missed. Many advantage points for great photographs. Plaudits for the superb restoration work of the many mausoleums.

This was the most beautiful and interesting place we saw in Samarkand, we usually don't like to go cemeteries, but these mausoleums are beautiful and for us the best cultural visit we do in Uzbekistan.

The beauty and wonder of all the different holy buildings as you climb the stairs is really astounding. The tile works are astounding with an array of blues that come from beyong the sea and sky. It is a climb so take water. Lots of people here as well but not ovewrhelming and
Inside this complex you will find a lot of buildings where the outside (and sometimes also the inside) is covered with mosaic, mostly in blue colors. Very fotogenic.

Shrine of Hazrat Kussum bin Abbas and many others well maintained and decorated, and the 40 stairs to climb at one go with requirement of just one foot at every step is a unique experience, thought it might relate only to stories and mythology.

Extremely crowded and renovated with some questionable liberties (please refer to the colours), yet it still makes for an impressive, somewhat solemn site. Comes with a ticket price of 10k som per person nowadays
This is a pilgrimage site for many people. The Alley of Mausoleums is amazing, and worth the visit all by itself. Superb tile work.

The Shah-I-Zinda, the ‘Tomb of the Living King’ originally dates from the ninth century, and is purported to be the final resting place of Qusam Ibn Abbas, a cousin of the Prophet Mohammed who brought Islam to the area in the seventh century. The name is derived from a legend

take your time when visiting shar - I Zindar. Of all the places (Buchara, Kiva) this was the most impressive location. Or take a 2nd time to come back at the end, before closing time like 17.00 hrs. I think its open till 18.00 hrs.

It's a necropolis with a complex of mausoleums and a adjacent cemetery and perhaps the most photogenic place in Samarkand! It's a must see for everybody visiting the city. Registan ist breathtaking, but this laying a bit on the outside complex is a real jewel! There is nothing

One of the top places to visit in Samarqand. A necropolis with tombs of several eras with fascinating geometrical patterns. The tourist part is built like a narrow street, with mausoleums on both sides (much stair climbing), used as religious site or tourist shop or just empty.
Its a must see. The ticket is 10k per person, 6k for camera. Huge complex, beautiful tombs and on your way back do not miss the cemetery!
Shah-i-Zinda is a must-see of Samarkand. It is a dense complex of mausoleums pertaining to proeminent dignitaries and wives of the emirs and of the nobility. Very nicely coloured, a jewel of art.

I thought this was a lovely place to visit. The buildings of the ensemble have beautiful detail and a blue color that I hadn't seen anywhere in my whole trip (this was seen on the last day). The cemetery is interesting as I had never gone to a muslim cemetery before, however it
.. i love staring at every detail of the buildings.. it's simply amazing.. i'll be going back to see more of this city as I had limited time during that visit..

This avenue of mausoleums leads up from the road up an avenue leading to the plateau. Both sides are smothered in tastefully done mausoleums all the way to the top. The mausoleums are tightly packed together and are all brightly decorated all with different patterns and designs.
A wonderful city which offers a lot from the past. One must visit it. An unforgettable place for me!!!!!!!

This is a burial place for mainly the wifes of the Emirs which are burried in Gur Emir Mausoleum and the mausoleums are wonderful. One tip: when you reach the last mausoleum on the right turn round behind it go for about 20-30 meters and then climb throughthe modern cemetry

Tombs, tombs and more tombs, or rather mausoleums, mausoleums and more mausoleums. Consists of an avenue of compact closely spaced brightly decorated mausoleums all of which have a slightly different Islamic architecture. Most of those buried here are from the mongol era,
Explore the beautiful buildings but also the cemetery on the surrounding hill. The late president was recently buried here.

This is a row of tombs and mausoleums that are collectively known as Shah-i-Zinda, or "place of a living king," stretched between the present and the past. At its front is living Samarkand, and at its back the dusty slopes at the edge of ancient Afrosiab.

A wonderful street full of turquoise tiles and mosaics, a madrassa, a mosque and many mausolea. Tempting to keep clicking away on the camera but just move to one side, stand in the shade and just look and absorb the splendour. It is so striking in both colour and size.

The concentration of mausoleums, the climb up the stairs and the "Avenue" of Mausoleums was beautiful and although there were souvenir shops it was nice to see they were not in located in the same rooms as the tombs. The walk through the cemetery and up the hill can yield great
Fascinating collection of mausoleums with a lot of locals visiting. Very moving and with a lot of soul.

This "Avenue of Mausoleums" with one of the richest tile work in the muslim world, was probably one of the most impressive experiences I have had with islamic architecture. We spent 2 hours there overwhelmed by this incredible concentration of beautiful views and impressions.

A fascinating place to visit, like many of the attractions in Samarkand. Apparently if you count the steps on your way up to the mausoleums and count them again when you descend and if the number is the same then you have a pure heart, or so my guide told me! The mausoleums

A study in the artistic possibilities of a limited palate: with brilliant turquoise and blue tiles, brick and a bit of black, white and gold leaf, no two of these buildings are the same. I was fascinated to realize that most of the decorations, even the most geometric and
This place was lovely even on a super hot day. Parts of it dating from the 9th century, well renovated and a small explanation in English on each mausoleum was great
Impossibly beautiful, fabulously concentrated and wonderfully presented, you'll spend hours in the Shah-i-Zinda marvelling at the majesty and other-worldliness of the forms and colours.

Come see these wonderfully adorned and unique tombs lining the one street of this necropolis. Temarlane's sisters and best friend are entombed here. The street culminates with a tomb of a purported relative of Mohammed. Apparently, he came to ensure the spread of Islam here
The Mausoleum is another must see sight in Samarkand but make sure you allow plenty of time as there is so much t o see.

Shah-i-Zinda was a highlight, the colours and architecture of each of the tombs and mausoleums are fantastic. We had a guide with us which was perfect as he explained each of the tombs/ mausoleums for us. While we were there they are doing some restoration to the entrance.
if you have time, you really should head slightly out of the centre of Samarkand to see these beautiful tombs. There are a number of buildings in the complex with some exquisite tile work.

It looks like a small village from afar, but up close you see that there are several building which house tombs of historically important people from Samarkand. The name means ‘Tomb of the Living King’. The buildings were eventually covered in earth and then rediscovered in

This Necropolis was my favorite Samarkand attraction. The tile work is the MOST BEAUTIFUL artwork I have seen.. EVER. I suggest you read about it ahead of time and not hire a guide for this. Great place for photography!

The Shah-i-Zinda is the other must-see sight in Samarkand. The tombs are peaceful, some with wonderful, ornate ceilings - others have plain whitewashed walls. A fantastic place to wander around for an hour or two. A taxi may be needed to get here (but this will not cost very

The 11 Shahi Zinda mausoleums are lined up facing each other on an uphill street. We loved them. Our guide Valentina gave us very good explanations for almost each of them and the best part was we spent quite a bit of time exploring. The best monument to explore in Samarkand.

What an amazing place. An uphill Street filled with mausoleums each if a different design. Great place to spend time and see things at a slow pace. Religious and Spiritual to believers and can be the same for others too.

I went near sunset in the hope of seeing marmosets. I read they appeared around then. They didn't but it was a good time to go - the golden sun on the tombs made for lovely photos. I imagine it would also be lovely in the early morning. If I'd had more time I would have gone

I thought Registan would be the highlight of our trip to Samarkand but this place blew us away. The size, complexity, and beauty were phenomenal and I could visit there many times without getting tired of the scene. A must see in Samarkand.

This was a place to take your breath away.Of all the places we visited this was my absolute favourite(even beats the Observatory).The climb to enter is wonderful and your eyes are all over the place trying to take in the wonder of the architecture and the colours. We went on

The Shah-i-zinda is a hidden gem, and a veritable must for any traveller on the Silk Road in Samarkand. From the outside, the complex appears quite unobtrusive - just a couple of ubiquitous turquoise blue-tiled domes sticking up - but once you have climbed the steep stairs up

A must-see when visiting Samarkand! This is a long narrow street of mausoleums that are absolutely beautiful. The individual architecture and detail of each is unique and they almost seem to be trying to out-do one another - the next one seems to better the previous one!

Shah-i-Zinda is a beautiful path of mausoleums that is a must see for any visit to Samarkand. Located a short distance out of the city, in the same direction as Ulugbek's Observatory and Afrosiab, Shah-i-Zinda is best visited in the morning or at sunset, it isn't recommended to
If you have not visited Shah-i-Zinda you have definitely missed the best part of Samarkand. It would be advisable to visit the place with a professional guide.
Shah-i-Zinda is one of the must visit places in Samarkand. Do not miss this place. Take time to observe and absorve each little part of the monument.

2 of the tomb here are equally pretty and there is a story about it. Kussam Ibni Abbas shrine is here too. For those would like to know more about Timurid Love, Culture, and Traditions this is exactly tourist places to visit.
in my opinion, this was the most beautiful site I saw in Samarqand. It reminded me of an old town with it's narrow stone paved streets. Definitely worth a visit.
Some Mausoleums are good and photo-worthy. Try to visit twice in the same day to take addvantaage of lighting.

For non-Muslims if you love architecture and historical buildings this is a must visit. You have to climb up 49 odd steps to reach up where you can visit tombs decorated with typical Uzbek design mosaics tiles. Great for photos where you can see a little more view of Samarkand.

Shah-i-Zinda Necropolis a remarkable complex of medieval Samarkand mausoleums and other cult buildings (over 20 in number), called ‘the street cemetery’ by the locals, is located near Bibi-Khanym Mosque on the slope of ancient Samarkand settlement Afrasiab
The mausoleums were in a variety of styles and the architecture was incredible. I highly recommend visiting here.

Found on the edge of the town center and snaking up the hillside of ancient Afrosiab, this burial place was one of the most memorable attractions I saw in Samarkand and, as my guide pointed out, one of the most important as well. We walked from the Registan to get here which
A truly unique place that is denitely worth the walk from the Registan. Does feature some steep steps.

We agree with other travelers that Shah-i-Zinda is at least as impressive as the Registan. (They are, of course, quite different.) You need a guide (or excellent guidebook) to understand who the people were who are buried in these mausoleums. Allow plenty of time, since each

Shah-i-Zinda is a huge memorial tomb complex. We did not know how to reach it, so from Khudzh Khidr mosque we crossed the cemetery and entered the architectural monument from the back side and nobody asked us to pay any fee. However, later on we realized that it costs 5.000
This place is out of this world, the architecture, the colors, the history... I recommend to visit it with a good tour guide so you will be able to understand all the history regarding Shah-i-Zinda.
